Applicable laws may restrict the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent from taking possession of certain collateral securing the notes located outside of the United States on enforcement or in an insolvency. In addition, certain jurisdictions restrict the ability of foreign entities to hold the benefit of security interests over certain assets. This may mean that the Notes Collateral Agent will be unable to benefit from security interests in certain collateral securing the notes located outside of the United States and may also restrict the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent to transfer collateral securing the notes into its name on enforcement or in an insolvency.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Notes Collateral Agent may not be able to receive security in foreign jurisdictions which is pari passu to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities.
Subsubsection Text: The lien of the Notes Collateral Agent in the collateral securing the notes will be created pursuant to security documents entered into with the Notes Collateral Agent and perfected in a manner that, under the laws applicable to the creation and priority of liens in the jurisdictions in which the collateral securing the notes is pledged, will give it, in many cases, as a matter of law, junior priority to the rights of the collateral agents under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. In such cases, holders of the notes will have to rely on the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement to provide first-priority liens on such assets subject to applicable law in such local jurisdictions, as the case may be. As a result, the first-priority lien of the holders of the notes with respect to the collateral securing the notes will be dependent on the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement, which will provide that the rights of the holders of the notes with respect to the collateral securing the notes are secured on a first-priority basis. The First Lien Intercreditor Agreement may not be recognized in certain jurisdictions.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Enforcing your rights as a holder of notes or under the related guarantees or collateral documents across multiple jurisdictions may prove difficult.
Subsubsection Text: The notes will be guaranteed by the Guarantors, which are organized under the laws of multiple jurisdictions, including England and Wales and the United States. In the event of a bankruptcy, insolvency or similar event, proceedings could be initiated in any of these jurisdictions, such that it is not possible to predict with certainty in which jurisdiction or jurisdictions insolvency or similar proceedings would be commenced, or the outcome of such proceedings. Such multijurisdictional proceedings are likely to be complex and costly for creditors and otherwise may result in greater uncertainty and delay regarding the enforcement of your rights. Your rights under the notes and the related guarantees and collateral documents will be subject to the insolvency and administrative laws of several jurisdictions, and there can be no assurance that you will be able to effectively enforce your rights in such complex, multiple bankruptcy, insolvency or similar proceedings. The insolvency laws of these jurisdictions may not be as favorable to your interests as creditors as the laws of the United States or other jurisdictions with which you may be familiar. In addition, the bankruptcy, insolvency, administrative and other laws of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ jurisdictions of organization may be materially different from, or in conflict with, each other, including in the areas of rights of creditors, priority ----- of government and other creditors, ability to obtain post-petition interest, fees, and expenses and duration of the proceedings. The application of these laws, or any conflict among them, could call into question whether any particular jurisdiction’s law should apply, adversely affect your ability to enforce your rights under the notes and the guarantees and collateral documents in these jurisdictions, or limit any amounts that you may receive.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to finance a change of control offer required by the indenture that will govern the notes.
Subsubsection Text: Upon a change of control triggering event, as defined under the indenture that will govern the notes, you will have the right to require the Issuer to offer to purchase all of the notes then outstanding at a price equal to 101% of the principal amount of the notes, plus accrued interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of purchase. In order to obtain sufficient funds to pay the purchase price of the outstanding notes, we expect that we would have to refinance the notes. We cannot assure you that we would be able to refinance the notes on reasonable terms, if at all. Our failure to offer to purchase all outstanding notes or to purchase all validly tendered notes would be an event of default under the indenture that will govern the notes. Such an event of default may cause the acceleration of our other debt, including debt under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. Our future debt also may contain restrictions on repayment requirements with respect to specified events or transactions that constitute a change of control under the indenture that will govern the notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We can enter into transactions like recapitalizations, reorganizations and other highly leveraged transactions that do not constitute a change of control but that could adversely affect the holders of the notes.
Subsubsection Text: Certain important corporate events, such as leveraged recapitalizations, may not, under the indenture that will govern the notes, constitute a “change of control” that would require the Issuer to purchase the notes, notwithstanding the fact that such corporate events could increase the level of our indebtedness or otherwise adversely affect our capital structure, credit ratings or the value of the notes. Therefore, we could, in the future, enter into certain transactions, including acquisitions, reorganizations, refinancings or other recapitalizations that would not constitute a change of control under the indenture that will govern the notes, but that could increase the amount of indebtedness outstanding at such time or otherwise affect our capital structure or credit ratings. The indenture that governs the notes also contains exceptions that permit us to undertake certain corporate and tax transactions without complying with the covenants contained in the indenture, including certain tax planning and tax reorganization transactions and reorganizations in preparation for any initial public offering. These transactions could permit value to be transferred from our company and our restricted subsidiaries, including additional tax distributions to our owners, without being subject to restrictions under the indenture. In addition, one of the circumstances under which a change of control may occur is upon the sale or disposition of “all or substantially all” of our assets. There is no precise established definition of the phrase “substantially all” under applicable law and the interpretation of that phrase will likely depend upon particular facts and circumstances. Accordingly, the ability of a holder of notes to require us to repurchase its notes as a result of a sale of less than all our assets to another person may be uncertain.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The change of control provisions under the indenture governing the notes will not require the Issuer to offer to purchase the notes upon certain specified change of control events.
Subsubsection Text: The occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a “change of control” under the indenture that will govern the notes will not be deemed to be a change of control triggering if (i) the consolidated total leverage ratio of the Company would be no greater than 6.00 to 1.00 on a pro forma basis as of the date of consummation of a permitted change of control (such date, the “Permitted Change of Control Effective Date”) (tested, at the Issuer’s option, on a pro forma basis as of the time of signing the applicable sale transaction), (ii) the new permitted holder shall either be (a)(I) a private equity fund, similar investment fund or sovereign wealth fund, or consortium of private equity funds, similar investment funds or sovereign wealth funds acting in concert that (x) (in the case of each such fund other than a sovereign wealth fund) invests, as a substantial part of its business, in companies that are not, at the time of investment, in financial distress, as determined by the Issuer in good faith, and (y) together with their affiliated funds, have committed capital and/or assets under management in excess of $1.0 billion and (II) a special purpose acquisition company sponsored by the person(s) described in clause (ii)(a)(I) above and (b) a strategic or other corporate business engaged directly or indirectly in a business reasonably related or similar to the Company’s business; provided, that, if ----- the new permitted holder is (a) an entity as set forth in subclause (ii)(a) above, the Company (or any successor thereof) shall have obtained a public corporate credit rating of at least B3 from Moody’s and B- from S&P or (b) an entity as set forth in subclause (ii)(b) above, the Company (or any successor thereof) shall have obtained a public corporate credit rating of at least Ba3 from Moody’s and BB- from S&P (in each case, after giving effect to the change of control and all transactions related thereto). For more details, see the section “Description of Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of Notes—Certain Definitions—Change of Control Triggering Event” and related definitions.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: An active trading market may not develop for the notes.
Subsubsection Text: We cannot assure you that an active trading market will develop for the notes. We do not intend to apply for listing of the notes on any securities exchange or on any automated dealer quotation system. Although we have been informed by certain of the initial purchasers that they currently intend to make a market for the notes, they are not obliged to do so and any market making may be discontinued at any time without notice. The liquidity of, and trading market for, the notes may also be adversely affected by, among other things: - changes in the overall market for securities similar to the notes; - changes in our financial performance or prospects; - the prospects for companies in our industry generally; - the number of holders of the notes; - the interest of securities dealers in making a market for the notes; - the conditions of the financial markets; and - prevailing interest rates. The condition of the financial markets and prevailing interest rates have fluctuated in the past and are likely to fluctuate in the future, which could have an adverse effect on the market prices of the notes. Historically, the market for non–investment grade debt has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities that are similar to the notes. We cannot assure you that the market, if any, for any of the notes will be free from similar disruptions or that any such disruptions may not adversely affect the prices at which you may sell your notes. In addition, subsequent to their initial issuance, the notes may trade at a discount from their initial offering price, depending upon prevailing interest rates, the market for similar notes, our performance and other factors.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the notes will not be entitled to registration rights, and we do not currently intend to register the notes under applicable securities laws. There are restrictions on your ability to transfer or resell the notes.
Subsubsection Text: The notes are being offered and sold pursuant to an exemption from registration under the Securities Act and applicable state securities laws, and we do not currently intend to register the notes. The holders of the notes will not be entitled to require us to register the notes for resale or otherwise. Therefore, you may transfer or resell the notes in the United States only in a transaction registered under or exempt from the registration requirements of the Securities Act and applicable state securities laws, and you may be required to bear the risk of your investment for an indefinite period of time. The Issuer is not obligated to register the notes under the Securities Act or to offer to exchange the notes in an exchange offer registered under the Securities Act. As a result, for so long as the notes remain outstanding, they may be transferred or resold only in transactions exempt from the registration requirements of federal and applicable state securities laws. It is your obligation to ensure that your offers and sales of notes comply with applicable securities laws. These restrictions could limit the liquidity or affect the price of the notes. Because the notes will be issued in the form of global notes and affiliates of the Issuer may hold interests in the global notes, the notes you hold may be subject to transfer restrictions until one year after the Issuer, or any affiliate of the Issuer, is no longer the ----- owner of such note or no longer holds an interest in such global note. This means that the notes you hold may be subject to transfer restrictions indefinitely. See “Plan of Distribution.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Certain actions in respect of defaults taken under the indenture that will govern the notes by beneficial owners with short positions in excess of their interests in the notes will be disregarded.
Subsubsection Text: By acceptance of the notes, each holder of notes agrees, in connection with any notice of Default (as defined below) or Event of Default (as defined below), notice of acceleration or instruction to the Trustee or the Notes Collateral Agent, if applicable, to provide a notice of Default or Event of Default, notice of acceleration or take any other action (a “Noteholder Direction”), to (i) deliver a written representation to the Issuer, the Trustee and the Notes Collateral Agent, if applicable, that such holder and any of its affiliates acting in concert with it in connection with its investment in the notes are not (or, in the case such holder is DTC or its nominee, that such holder is being instructed solely by beneficial owners that are not) Net Short (as defined under “Description of Notes”) and (ii) provide the Issuer with such other information as the Issuer may reasonably request from time to time in order to verify the accuracy of such holder’s representation within five business days of request therefor. Holders of the notes, including holders that have hedged their exposure to the notes in the ordinary course and not for speculative purposes, may not be able to make such representations or provide the requested additional information. These restrictions may impact a holder’s ability to participate in Noteholder Directions if it is unable to make such a representation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We will not be subject to the Sarbanes–Oxley Act of 2002.
Subsubsection Text: Since we will not register the notes under the Securities Act after the offering, we will not be subject to the Sarbanes– Oxley Act of 2002 (“SOX”), which requires public companies to have and maintain effective disclosure controls and procedures to ensure timely disclosure of material information, and have management review the effectiveness of those controls on a quarterly basis. SOX also requires public companies to have and maintain effective internal control over financial reporting to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and preparation of financial statements, and have management review the effectiveness of those controls on an annual basis (and have the independent auditor attest to the effectiveness of such internal controls). We will not be required to comply with these requirements and therefore we will not have comparable procedures in place as compared to public companies.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are not providing all of the information that would be required if this offering were being registered with the SEC.
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum does not include all of the information that would be required if we were registering the offering of notes with the SEC. This lack of information could impair your ability to evaluate your investment in the notes. We cannot assure you that the historical and pro forma financial information as set forth in this offering memorandum will be indicative of our future financial performance or our ability to meet our obligations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: A lowering or withdrawal of the ratings assigned to our debt securities by rating agencies may adversely affect the market price or liquidity of the notes.
Subsubsection Text: Credit rating agencies continually revise their ratings for the companies that they follow, including us. Credit rating agencies also evaluate our industry as a whole and may change their credit ratings for us based on their overall view of our industry. The notes offered hereby will have a non–investment grade rating on the issue date. There can be no assurances that such rating will remain for any given period of time or that such rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by a rating agency if, in that rating agency’s judgment, future circumstances relating to the basis of the rating, such as adverse changes, so warrant. Credit ratings are not recommendations to purchase, hold or sell the notes, and may be revised or withdrawn at any time. Additionally, credit ratings may not reflect the potential effect of risks relating to the structure or marketing of the notes. If the credit rating of the notes is subsequently lowered or withdrawn for any reason, you may not be able to resell your notes without a substantial discount. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The indenture that will govern the notes will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act, and we will not be required to comply with the provisions of the Trust Indenture Act.
Subsubsection Text: The indenture that will govern the notes will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “Trust Indenture Act”), and we will not be required to comply with the provisions of the Trust Indenture Act. Therefore, holders of the notes will not be entitled to the benefit of the provisions and protection of the Trust Indenture Act except to the extent there are similar provisions in the indenture that will govern the notes. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: _An investment in the notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the information included in this offering memorandum before deciding whether to purchase the notes. Any of the following risks may materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties that we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. In such a case, you may lose all or part of your original investment. The risks discussed below also include forward–looking statements, and our actual results may differ substantially from those discussed in these forward–looking statements. See “Forward–looking Statements” in this offering memorandum._

Section Title: USE OF PROCEEDS
Subsubsection Text: We estimate that our net proceeds from this offering, after deducting initial purchaser discounts and commissions and estimated expenses payable by us, will be approximately $    million. We intend to use the net proceeds from the offering of the notes, together with borrowings under our Incremental First Lien Term Loan Facilities, proceeds from the Equity Contribution and cash on hand, to (i) finance and consummate the AMC Acquisition and (ii) pay transaction expenses and fees in connection with the foregoing. The initial purchasers or their respective affiliates have made commitments to us with respect to the increased commitments under the Extended First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, the Incremental Senior Secured Credit Facilities and a senior secured bridge facility, in each case, to finance a portion of the Transactions or for general corporate purposes, and will receive customary fees in connection with such commitments. The proceeds of the notes, together with a portion of the Incremental First Lien Term Loan Facilities, will reduce the bridge commitments in full. The table below sets forth the estimated sources and uses of funds in connection with this offering, based on estimated amounts outstanding at the closing of this offering. Actual amounts may vary from the estimated amounts shown below depending on several factors, including accrued interest on our indebtedness, working capital needs and differences from our estimated fees, costs, and expenses. You should read the following together with the information included under the sections entitled “Capitalization” and “Summary––Summary Historical and Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information” included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsection Title: NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION Note 1. Basis of Presentation
Subsubsection Text: The historical audited consolidated financial statements for Rocket and audited combined carveout financial statements for the AMC business have been adjusted in the accompanying unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information to give effect to certain pro forma events that are directly attributable to the Transactions and are factually supportable. Both the Rocket and AMC business historical financial statements were prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and presented in U.S. dollars. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information was prepared using the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with ASC 805, with Rocket determined to be the accounting acquirer based on preliminary analysis of the Acquisition Agreement and based on the historical audited consolidated financial statements of Rocket and the historical audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business. Under ASC 805, assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination are recognized and measured at their assumed acquisition date fair value, while transaction costs associated with a business combination are expensed as incurred. The excess of acquisition consideration over the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed, if any, is allocated to goodwill. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet as of December 31, 2023 is presented as if the Transactions had occurred on December 31, 2023 and the unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations and comprehensive income (loss) for the year ended December 31, 2023 give effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on January 1, 2023. There were no material transactions between Rocket and the AMC business during the period presented. Accordingly, adjustments to eliminate transactions between Rocket and the AMC business have not been reflected in the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information presented herein. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and do not represent the consolidated balance sheet or consolidated results of operations and comprehensive income had the Transactions been completed as of the dates indicated. The pro forma adjustments have been made on available information and on assumptions that management believes are reasonable under the circumstances to reflect, on a pro forma basis, the impact of the Transactions on the historical financial information. See the notes to the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information below for a discussion of certain assumptions made. The unaudited pro forma combined financial information does not project the combined company’s results of the operations or financial position for any future period or date. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the AMC Acquisition—The pro forma financial statements included in this offering memorandum are presented for illustrative purposes only and may not be an indication of our financial condition or results of operation following consummation of the AMC Acquisition. This offering memorandum includes financial and operational information derived from information prepared by other entities, which our management cannot independently verify.”

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: (a) To record differences in accounting policy for accounts receivable and deferred revenue. The AMC business elects to net accounts receivables against deferred revenue for contracts not commenced. This adjustment is to reflect the gross impact of the accounts receivables and deferred revenue to align with Rocket’s policy. The total balance of $32.2 million increases the accounts receivable and deferred revenue balances. (b) To record Rocket identified differences in policy for the accrual of certain maintenance revenue. Historical results of the AMC business results include revenue accruals for certain revenue that is not billable as of the close of a period. Rocket has elected to apply a practical expedient for such revenue to record as it becomes billable. The resulting adjustment reduces accounts receivable by $2.0 million and reduces revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023 by $1.3 million. The pro forma tax effect is calculated using the estimated blended statutory tax rate of approximately 22.6%.

Subsection Title: Note 4. Adjustments to Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Balance Sheet Transaction Accounting Adjustments
Subsubsection Text: The AMC Acquisition will be accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with ASC 805, which requires, among other things, that the assets acquired, and liabilities assumed be recognized at their acquisition closing date fair values, with any excess of the consideration transferred over the estimated fair values of the identifiable net assets acquired, if any, recorded as goodwill. The accounting for the acquisition is based on currently available information and is considered preliminary. The final accounting for the acquisition may differ materially from that presented in this unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2023 includes approximately $9.5 ----- million of transaction expenses, and estimated transaction costs through the AMC Acquisition closing are not considered material. _A._ _Estimated Purchase Consideration_ The estimated purchase consideration is $2.275 billion. This Purchase Consideration will be paid on the consummation of the Transactions and is reflected as a reduction to cash in the unaudited condensed combined balance sheet. The Purchase Consideration is to be funded with cash on hand and the Financing Transactions undertaken by Rocket as discussed in Note 2. _B._ _Preliminary Purchase_ _Price Allocation_ The following table summarized the preliminary aggregate purchase price allocation by major categories of assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on the preliminary estimate of fair values. Subsubsection Text: The preliminary purchase accounting was based on an initial valuation in order to identify fair value allocations of transaction considerations to assets acquired and liabilities assumed including intangible assets and step-up in the value of property and equipment. Following the consummation of the AMC Acquisition, a final determination of the fair value of the AMC business’s assets and liabilities will be performed. The final acquisition consideration allocation may be materially different than that reflected in the preliminary estimated acquisition consideration allocation presented herein. Any increase or decrease in fair values of the net assets as compared with the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information may change the amount of the total acquisition consideration allocated to goodwill and other assets and liabilities and may have a material impact on the combined company’s future results of operations and financial position. _C._ _Preliminary Identified Intangible Assets_ ----- The preliminary estimated fair value adjustment to the identifiable intangible assets to be acquired in the Transaction is shown in the table below. (6,999) Pro forma net adjustment to intangible assets .........................................................................................** $ 1,388,501 _D._ _Deferred Tax Liabilities_ The pro forma adjustment for deferred tax liabilities reflects deferred taxes resulting from pro forma fair value adjustments related to the acquired intangible assets. Based on the preliminary estimate of intangible assets by jurisdiction, deferred tax liabilities have been estimated as the book-tax difference by jurisdiction considering the effective tax rate expected in that jurisdiction. The estimated deferred tax liability resulting from the fair value adjustments is approximately $100.3 million. Because the tax rates used for the pro forma financial information are estimated, the estimated blended statutory tax rate by jurisdiction will likely vary from the actual effective rate in periods subsequent to the consummation of the AMC Acquisition. This determination is preliminary and subject to change based upon the final determination of the fair value of the acquired intangible assets.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The following unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information of Rocket and the AMC business as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 is derived from Rocket’s historical audited consolidated financial statements, which are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, and the AMC business’s audited historical combined carveout financial statements, which have been prepared specifically for the purpose of the AMC Acquisition and which are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, presented on a “carve-out” basis from (i) Micro Focus’s accounting records for the period from January 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023 and (ii) OpenText’s accounting records for the period from and after February 1, 2023. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information is presented as follows: - The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet as of December 31, 2023 was prepared based on (i) the historical audited consolidated balance sheet of Rocket as of December 31, 2023 and (ii) the historical audited combined carveout balance sheet of the AMC business as of December 31, 2023. - The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations and comprehensive income (loss) for the year ended December 31, 2023 was prepared based on (i) the historical consolidated statement of operations and comprehensive income of Rocket for the year ended December 31, 2023 and (ii) the historical audited combined carveout statement of income and comprehensive income of the AMC business for the year ended December 31, 2023. The base purchase price for the AMC Acquisition is a cash payment of $2.275 billion (the “Purchase Consideration”), subject to customary net working capital adjustments and indebtedness as set forth in the Acquisition Agreement (collectively, the “Purchase Price”). The Purchase Consideration is to be funded from cash on hand and additional debt equity commitments (as defined herein) (collectively, for purpose of this section, the “Financing Transactions”). See _Note 2, Basis of Presentation, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies and Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements_ to Rocket’s audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for further information. The AMC Acquisition is expected to close substantially concurrently with or promptly after the closing of this offering of the notes. The AMC Acquisition will be accounted for as a business combination using the acquisition method with Rocket as the accounting acquirer in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification Topic 805, Business Combinations (“ASC 805”). Under this method of accounting, the total consideration will be allocated to the AMC business’s assets acquired and liabilities assumed based upon their estimated fair values, with limited exception for acquired deferred revenue balance, as of the closing date of the AMC Acquisition. The process of valuing the net assets of the AMC business at the expected closing date of the AMC Acquisition, as well as evaluating accounting policies for conformity, is preliminary. Any differences between the fair value of the consideration transferred and the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed will be recorded as goodwill. Accordingly, the purchase price allocation reflected in this unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information is preliminary and subject to revision based on a final determination of fair value and final adjustments to the Purchase Price. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information is based on the preliminary information available and management’s preliminary valuation of the fair value of intangible and tangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Certain assets and liabilities acquired, as well as the working capital adjustments, will be valued as part of the final purchase accounting assessment and have not been fully considered in the preliminary valuation. Accordingly, the actual purchase accounting assessment may vary based on final analyses of the valuation of assets to be acquired and liabilities to be assumed, particularly in regard to definite-lived intangible assets and deferred tax assets and liabilities, which could be material. The financial information included in this “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” section is not intended to comply with the requirements of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act and the rules and regulations of the SEC promulgated thereunder. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information and related notes are provided for informational purposes only and do not purport to represent what the combined company’s actual results of operations or financial position would have been had the Transactions been completed on ----- the dates indicated, nor are they necessarily indicative of the combined company’s future results of operations or financial position for any future period. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information is based on information and assumptions that are described in the accompanying notes. The actual financial position and results of operations may differ significantly from the pro forma amounts reflected herein. Further, the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information does not reflect any anticipated synergies or dis-synergies, operating efficiencies or cost savings that may result from the AMC Acquisition or any integration costs that may be incurred. The results and balances reflected herein are not intended to be a projection of future financial position or results of operations of Rocket following the completion of the Transactions, which may vary materially from the results reflected because of various factors. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet is presented as if the Transactions had occurred on December 31, 2023, and the unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations and comprehensive income (loss) for the year ended December 31, 2023 is presented as if the Transactions had occurred on January 1, 2023. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information presented herein has been derived from: - Rocket’s historical audited consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023; and - The AMC business’s audited combined carveout financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, prepared specifically for the purpose of the AMC Acquisition, which are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The following unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information gives effect to the Transactions, which includes adjustments for the following: - Certain reclassification and accounting policy alignment adjustments to conform the AMC business’s historical financial statement presentation to Rocket’s presentation; - The application of the acquisition method of accounting under the provisions of ASC 805; and - The uses of proceeds of the Financing Transactions consummated in connection with the Transactions. This unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information should be read in conjunction with the historical audited consolidated financial statements of Rocket, the historical audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business, “Rocket’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “AMC Business’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and other sections included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. -----

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On November 28, 2023, Rocket entered into the Acquisition Agreement with OpenText, pursuant to which OpenText has agreed to divest, directly and indirectly through certain subsidiaries, its AMC business and Rocket has agreed to purchase the same and generally assume certain liabilities related to the AMC business, as set forth in the Acquisition Agreement, for an all-cash purchase price of $2.275 billion, before taxes, fees and other adjustments. On August 31, 2023, Rocket, through its wholly owned subsidiary, Rocket Software Deutschland GmbH, acquired 100% of the equity interest in BOS DigiTec GmbH (“BOS”), a private company based in Munich, Germany for a purchase price of $17.8 million, net of cash acquired of $4.9 million. On February 28, 2023, the Company acquired 100% of the equity interest in Key Resources, Inc. (“KRI”) for a purchase price of $2.2 million, net of cash acquired of $0.1 million. The KRI purchase agreement includes contingent payments of up to $4.0 million, payable to two former shareholders of KRI in annual installments over a three-year period following the closing date, to the extent certain financial performance and employee retention conditions are met. The Company has determined the contingent payments to be a post-combination compensation arrangement and will accrue for the expected cost over the period in which the compensation is considered probable and earned. As of December 31, 2023, the Company has accrued $2.2 million of expense which is recorded in General and administrative expenses within the statement of operations.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Rocket Software, Inc. is a leading global enterprise software provider with a broad portfolio of products that help corporations, government agencies and other organizations operate, optimize and modernize their mission-critical IT infrastructure. The Company’s software solutions run, optimize, and protect customers’ servers and databases, as well as connect their systems to the rest of the enterprise. The products the Company provides enable customers to carry out their most mission-critical business functions, such as processing payment transactions at global financial institutions and maintaining healthcare records at hospitals and insurance companies. Since the Company’s founding over 30 years ago, the Company has cultivated a customer-centric culture with strategic investments in research and development that provide a wide range of offerings to continuously meet customers’ evolving needs. Rocket meets customers wherever they are on their modernization journeys—whether modernizing on premise or through a hybrid cloud strategy. With over 10,000 global customers, Rocket solves enterprises’ most complex IT challenges, across infrastructure, data and applications.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The Company generates revenues from the sale of enterprise software products and solutions through branded direct sales to enterprise customers that help corporations, government agencies and other organizations reach their technology and business goals. The Company also licenses products to original equipment manufacturer (“OEM”) partners, predominantly represented by IBM, independent software vendor (“ISV”) partners, reseller partners; to provide partners and customers solutions, features, and flexibility through service and support businesses; and to acquire and integrate businesses with similar technology, customers, platforms, and sales channels. Revenue growth is dependent on the ability to sell software products with maintenance and support. License revenue consists of products sold on a perpetual or fixed term basis that generally ranges from one to five years. Maintenance revenue consists of technical support, bug fixes, and when-and-if available unspecified software upgrades. Maintenance contracts generally have an annual term with optional renewal terms or may be bundled in a fixed term license arrangement. Subscription revenue consists of several software as a service (“SaaS”) hosted offerings and OEM royalty revenue. SaaS hosted offerings are sold via a subscription-based model. Professional service revenue consists primarily of consulting and training services and may be bundled or sold on a stand-alone basis.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Cost of Revenues and Gross Profit
Subsubsection Text: Cost of revenue consists primarily of salaries, benefits and bonuses for employees directly associated with customer support, software purchased for resale, and amortization of acquired intangibles for purchased technology. Gross profit may vary from quarter to quarter and is primarily affected by revenue and purchased technology amortization, which varies based on the timing of acquisitions and the related fair values determined in purchase accounting.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Research and development expenses consist primarily of employee-related costs for the design and development of technology and contractor costs to supplement staff levels. The Company devotes substantial resources to research and development in an effort to maintain a competitive position. The Company expects that research and development expense will increase as its business grows, particularly as the Company incurs additional costs related to continued investments in its platform and products.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Sales and marketing expenses consist primarily of employee-related costs directly associated with sales and marketing staff and commissions. Other sales and marketing costs include marketing programs and promotional events to promote the Company’s brands. Certain sales commissions earned by the sales force are deferred and amortized on a straight-line basis over the period of contract performance or a longer period, generally the expected life of the customer relationship. The expected customer relationship period is determined based on average historical customer relationship periods, including expected renewals. Expected renewal periods are only included in the expected customer relationship period if commission amounts paid upon renewal are not commensurate with amounts paid on the initial contract. Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs incurred to obtain a contract that would not have been incurred if the contract had not been obtained. The Company has determined that certain commissions programs meet the requirements to be deferred. The Company groups similar contracts based on revenue and customer type and amortizes commissions on a systemic basis over the average contract length or expected customer life.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: General and administrative expenses consist primarily of employee-related costs for executive, finance, legal, human resources, IT, and administrative personnel, professional fees for external legal, accounting, recruiting and other consulting services, facility costs, and depreciation of property and equipment. These expenses also include management fees payable to Bain Capital Private Equity, LP. -----

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Amortization of Other Acquired Intangible Assets
Subsubsection Text: Amortization of other acquired intangible assets consists primarily of the amortization of acquired intangible assets, excluding amortization of purchased technology and backlog. Amortization may vary from quarter to quarter and is primarily affected by acquired intangible assets, which varies based on the timing of acquisitions and the related fair values determined in purchase accounting.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Interest expense consists primarily of contractual interest expense on long-term debt, including senior notes, a first lien term loan, a first lien revolving line of credit, acquired debt from the 2019 acquisition of Sixon Holding SA, and the amortization of debt issuance costs. As discussed in _Note 15, Derivatives, to the audited consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, the Company entered into interest rate swaps and caps for a portion of debt, and the realized gains or losses from those derivatives are recorded as a component of interest expense. The Company expects interest expense to decrease when indebtedness is repaid or when interest rate fall. The Company expects interest expense to increase when indebtedness is borrowed and when interest rates rise.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Other income (expense), net consists primarily of gains and losses on sale of investments, foreign currency transactions and remeasurements, and remeasurements or settlements of non-hedge designated derivative instruments. The Company’s reporting currency is the U.S. dollar. With respect to non-U.S. subsidiaries, the functional currency is the local currency.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Provision (benefit) for income taxes consists of US federal, state, and foreign income taxes related to the jurisdictions in which the Company operates. Deferred income taxes are provided for differences between the financial statement and tax basis of assets and liabilities and for tax net operating loss and credit carry forwards using enacted tax rates expected to be in effect in the years in which the differences are expected to reverse. Valuation allowances are provided for deferred tax assets that, based on currently available evidence, may not be realized. The Company records a liability associated with an uncertain tax position if it is determined that there is not a more likely than not possibility of sustaining such benefit upon audit by the taxing authority based on the technical merits of the position. The Company records a tax benefit of a position as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For the year ended December 31, 2023, net cash provided by investing activities was $31.6 million, primarily related to proceeds from settlement of derivatives and the gain on investment in Software AG, partially offset by purchases of property and equipment and the acquisitions of KRI and BOS. For the year ended December 31, 2022, net cash used in investing activities was $6.2 million, primarily related to purchases of property and equipment. For the year ended December 31, 2022, net cash used in investing activities was $6.2 million primarily related to purchases of property and equipment offset by realized gains on the settlement on derivatives. For the year ended December 31, 2021, net cash used in investing activities was $1,084.7 million, of which $222.4 million related to the purchase of Uniface and $828.0 million related to the purchase of ASG.

For the year ended December 31, 2022, net cash used in financing activities was $26.2 million, primarily consisting of $20.9 million in debt principal payments and $2.6 million of and finance lease payments. For the year ended December 31, 2022, net cash used in financing activities was $26.2 million, primarily consisting of $20.9 million in debt principal payments and $2.6 million of finance lease payments. For the year ended December 31, 2021, net cash provided by financing activities was $1,002.5 million, consisting of the issuance of $575.0 million in Existing Notes and $828.1 million in proceeds from the Existing First Lien Term Loans, partially offset by payments of $260.0 million on the Company’s second lien term loan and $62.0 million in net payments on the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility.

ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In December 2023, the Company announced its decision to exit its operations in China as a broader initiative to colocate many of its application modernization products at the Company’s development centers located in Vilnius, Lithuania; Pune, India; and Bentonville, Arkansas. The estimated cost of the program is $16.0 to $18.0 million and it is expected to be completed in early 2025. The Company recorded $7.3 million of employee-related restructuring costs within operating expenses in the fourth quarter of 2023. The plan is not expected to generate savings. In July 2023, the Company’s management approved a plan to reduce its global workforce by approximately 5%. The plan was substantially completed during the quarter ended September 30, 2023 at a cost of $6.4 million. Upon completion of the plan, the Company expects to generate approximately $14.0 million of annualized savings. During 2021, the Company announced a global reorganization and facilities consolidation plan to reduce redundancies and achieve synergies relating to the integration of the Company’s acquisitions of M4 Global Solutions Holding Coöperatief U.A. and its wholly owned subsidiary, Uniface B.V. (collectively, “Uniface”) and ASG Everglades Holdings, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiary, ASG Technologies Holdings, Inc., ASG Technologies Group, Inc. (collectively, “ASG”). The total cost of the plan was $57.2 million and was completed in the second quarter of 2023. The plan included restructuring-related costs such as employee severance, other employee-related costs, asset impairments and accelerated depreciation, facility exit costs as well as consulting fees relating to integrations. The Company expects to generate approximately $50.0 million of annualized savings.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: During 2021, the Company began executing a global reorganization and facilities consolidation plan to reduce redundancies and achieve synergies relating to the integration of the Company’s acquisitions of Uniface and ASG. The total estimated cost of the plan is $55 to $60 million of which $54.1 million has been incurred to date through December 31, 2022. The plan includes restructuring-related costs such as employee severance, other employee-related costs, asset impairments and accelerated depreciation, facility exit costs as well as consulting fees relating to integrations. The majority of the cost of the plan is expected to be incurred by March 31, 2023. The plan was expected to generate $45 to $50 million of annualized savings, the majority of which has been realized as of December 31, 2022.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Cash, Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents are primarily comprised of bank deposits and money market funds held with global relationship banks. As of December 31, 2023 and 2022, the Company had $239.0 million and $157.8 million, respectively, of unrestricted cash. These amounts do not include restricted cash, which primarily represents deposits on lease facilities and are included in prepaid expense, other current assets, and other assets. The Company had net working capital (defined as current assets less current liabilities) of $136.4 million, $88.3 million and ($3.9) million as of December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. The primary sources of liquidity include existing unrestricted cash, cash flow generated from operations, and borrowings from the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility. As of December 31, 2023, the Company had $151.7 million available for additional borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, after giving effect to $1.2 million of letters of credit issued thereunder. As of December 31, 2023, the Company had cash requirements of $215.0 million for estimated interest payments over the next 12 months. The Company also has cash requirements related to principal debt obligation and lease payments. See Note 10, Long-Term Debt and Note 11, Leases to the audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for a description of long-term debt obligations and lease commitments, respectively. The Company anticipates using existing cash and proceeds from operating cash flows to fund these expenditures. Liquidity needs primarily include meeting debt service requirements, working capital requirements and capital expenditures. The Company may also pursue strategic acquisition opportunities that may impact future cash requirements. There are certain factors that may negatively impact available sources of funds in the future including the ability to generate cash from operations and borrow on debt facilities. The amount of cash generated from operations is dependent upon factors such as the successful execution of business strategies and general economic conditions. The amount of cash available for borrowings under various debt facilities is dependent on the ability to maintain sufficient collateral and general financial conditions in the marketplace.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On November 28, 2018, in connection with the completion of Bain Capital’s acquisition of the Company, the Company entered into a credit agreement with Royal Bank of Canada (as successor to Credit Suisse AG, Cayman Islands Branch), as administrative agent, and the lenders party thereto, which, as amended through December 31, 2023, provides for (i) a first lien term loan in an aggregate principal amount of approximately $1,410 million in U.S. dollar-denominated term loans (the “Existing Dollar Term Loan”) and an aggregate principal amount of €575 million Euro-denominated term loans (after giving effect to amortization payments made prior to the date hereof) (the “Existing Euro Term Loan” and, together with the Existing Dollar Term Loan, the “Existing First Lien Term Loans”), and (ii) a revolving loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of up to approximately $152.9 million (the “Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility” and, together with the Existing First Lien Term Loans, the Incremental First Lien Term Loan Facilities (as described elsewhere) and the Extended First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities”). As of December 31, 2023, the Existing Dollar Term Loan had a balance of $1,403.9 million and the Existing Euro Term Loan, translated in U.S. dollars, had an outstanding balance of $635.2 million. As of December 31, 2023, the Company had $152.9 million in borrowings available under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility (without giving effect to $1 million of letters of credit issued thereunder). Under the terms of the Existing Dollar Term Loan, the principal amount is paid in quarterly installments equal to 1.0% of the original principal amount per annum until the final maturity date, when the remaining principal is due and monthly floating interest rate payments are made based on the one-month SOFR rate. The interest rate per annum applicable to the Existing Dollar Term Loan is the adjusted SOFR rate (with a minimum of 0.50% per annum) plus 4.75%. Under the terms of the Existing Euro Term Loan, the Company will make monthly floating interest rate payments based on the one-month EURIBOR rate. The interest rate per annum applicable to the Existing Euro Term Loan is the adjusted EURIBOR rate (with a minimum of 0.00% per annum) plus 4.75%. ----- The interest rate per annum applicable to borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility is, at the option of the Company, the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.25% or the alternative base rate plus 2.25%, with step-downs to (i) the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.125% or the alternative base rate plus 2.125%, as applicable, and (ii) the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.00% or the alternative base rate plus 2.00%, as applicable, in each case based on achieving certain First Lien Net Leverage Ratios, as defined in the credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Term Loans and the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility. The credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility contains a financial covenant that requires compliance with a maximum First Lien Net Leverage Ratio of 7.70 to 1.00 if, on the last day of any quarter, the amount of borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility is greater than 35% of the aggregate outstanding revolving commitments. The covenant did not apply to the Company as of December 31, 2023. The Existing First Lien Term Loans and the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility contain certain mandatory prepayment requirements, including, with respect to the Existing First Lien Term Loans, 50% (with step downs to 25% and 0% based on achieving certain leverage ratios) of annual excess cash flow greater than $15.0 million in any fiscal year. See also “Description of Other Indebtedness.”

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of August 16, 2019, the Company assumed indebtedness in connection with the acquisition of Sixon Holding SA (the “RSD Debt”). Pursuant to the credit agreement governing the RSD Debt, dated September 19, 2018, the RSD Debt consists of a CHF 17.5 million senior amortizing term loan facility and a CHF 17.5 million senior non-amortizing (bullet) term loan facility. The amortizing term loan facility is subject to mandatory repayments of CHF 3.2 million, payable annually on December 31st through 2022, with a final payment of CHF 3.2 million due on March 28, 2024 (which payment was made). The non-amortizing term loan facility, which consists of U.S. dollar-denominated facilities and Euro-denominated facilities, has a maturity date of September 28, 2024. As of December 31, 2023, the outstanding amount, translated into U.S. dollars, under the RSD Debt was $19.7 million. The interest rate per annum applicable to the U.S. dollar-denominated facilities is, at the option of the Company, the adjusted SOFR rate plus the Alternative Reference Rates Committee spread plus a blended rate of 2.6%. The interest rate per annum applicable to the Euro-denominated facilities is, at the option of the Company, the adjusted EURIBOR rate plus a blended rate of 2.4%.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On February 2, 2021, in connection with the Company’s acquisition of Uniface, the Company issued $575.0 million in aggregate principal amount of 6.500% Senior Notes due 2029 (the “Existing Notes”). The Company used the net proceeds from the offering of the notes, together with cash on hand, (i) to finance and consummate the acquisition of Uniface, (ii) to repay in full the outstanding indebtedness and accrued interest under the second lien term loan, (iii) to pay down all then outstanding borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, (iv) to pay transaction expenses and fees and (v) for other general corporate purposes. The Existing Notes are unsecured and bear interest at a rate of 6.500% per year. Interest on the notes is payable semiannually, in arrears, on February 15 and August 15 of each year. The Existing Notes have a maturity date of February 15, 2029. For further information, see _Note 10, Long Term Debt to our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On January 10, 2019, the Company entered into interest rate swap agreements to fix the rate on $1,015.0 million of the then-outstanding balance of $1,300.0 million under the Existing First Lien Term Loans. The Company pays a ----- blended fixed rate of 2.51% per annum and receives floating rate interest at December 31, 2023. These swaps have maturity dates of January 31, 2024. The interest rate swaps, designated for hedge accounting, are recorded at fair value on the balance sheet and changes in the fair value are recognized in other comprehensive income. The notional amount of these transactions was $1,015.0 million and had a fair value of $2.4 million, $24.6 million and $(35.7) million as of December 31, 2023, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively. On August 12, 2021, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement, which has a maturity date of November 28, 2025, to fix the rate on a portion of floating-rate debt. The rate is fixed at 5.23% per annum at December 31, 2023. The counterparty pays floating-rate interest plus a 4.29% spread. The interest rate swap, designated for hedge accounting, is recorded at fair value on the balance sheet and changes in the fair value are recognized in other comprehensive income. The notional amount of this transaction was $150.0 million and had a fair value asset of $8.7 million, $13.3 million and $1.9 million as of December 31, 2023, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On August 12, 2021, the Company entered into two interest rate cap agreements, one denominated in U.S. dollars and one in Euro, to cap the interest rate on a portion of U.S. dollar and Euro-denominated floating-rate debt. The agreements have a maturity date of August 31, 2024. The interest rate is capped at 1.5% per annum for the U.S. dollardenominated instrument and at 0.0% per annum for the Euro-denominated instrument at December 31, 2023. The interest rate caps, designated for hedge accounting, are recorded at fair value on the balance sheet and changes in the fair value are recognized in other comprehensive income. The notional amounts of these transactions were €300.0 million and $154.0 million and had a fair value of $10.7 million, $23.2 million and $1.5 million as of December 31, 2023, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively. In the second quarter of 2021, the Company acquired an interest rate cap agreement through the ASG acquisition. The agreement has matured as of October 31, 2023. The debt to which the interest rate cap related was paid off at the acquisition date. The interest rate cap, not designated for hedge accounting, is recorded at fair value on the balance sheet and changes in the fair value are recognized in Other income, net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The notional amount of this transaction was $200.0 million and had a fair value of $0.0 million, $6.3 million and $0.8 million as of December 31, 2023, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: On August 12, 2021, the Company entered into two cross-currency swap agreements: one agreement to protect a designated amount of the Company’s net investment in Rocket Software UK International, a British pound-functionalcurrency consolidated subsidiary (the British pound-U.S. dollar instrument) and one to cover the income-statement exposure to Euro foreign exchange fluctuations (the Euro-U.S. dollar instrument). The agreements have a maturity date of November 28, 2025. In conjunction with the amendment to its credit agreements that occurred on October 5, 2023, the Company settled and unwound its Euro-U.S. dollar instrument in the fourth quarter of 2023, resulting in cash proceeds of $37.1 million. This gain has been recognized in Other income (expense) over the life of the contract through mark to market. The Company recognized a gain of $2.4 million and $32.2 million as of December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, respectively. Both cross-currency swap agreements are recorded at fair value on the balance sheet. The British pound-U.S. dollar instrument is designated as a net investment hedge and changes in the fair value are recognized in other comprehensive income. The Euro-U.S. dollar instrument is not designated as a hedge and changes in fair value are recognized in ----- Other income, net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The notional amounts of these transactions, as of December 31, 2023 were £108.5 million and €0.0 million and had a fair value of $11.2 million. The notional amounts of these transactions, as of December 31, 2022 were £108.5 million and €191.8 million and had a fair value of $58.9 million. The notional amounts of these transactions, as of December 31, 2021 were £108.5 million and $191.8 million and had a fair value of $10.6 million. For the British pound-U.S. dollar instrument, the Company pays a fixed rate of 5.4% on the British pound leg of the contract and the counterparty pays the Company a fixed rate of 5.23% on the notional U.S. dollar amount of $150.0 million. Prior to the settlement of the Euro-U.S. dollar instrument, the Company paid a fixed rate of 4.16% on the Euro leg of the contract and the counterparty paid the Company floating-rate interest plus a 4.25% spread on the notional U.S. dollar amount of $225.0 million.
