Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies and Significant Management Estimates
Subsubsection Title: Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Credit Losses
Subsubsection Text: Accounts receivable are stated as the amount the Company’s management expects to collect from outstanding balances. Management reviews accounts receivable on a periodic basis to determine if any receivables will potentially be uncollectible. The Company reserves for receivables that are determined to be uncollectible, if any, in its allowance for credit losses. The allowance is based upon the credit worthiness of customers, historical experience, the age of the receivable and current market and economic conditions. After all attempts to collect a receivable have failed, the receivable is written off against the allowance. The following is a roll-forward of the Company’s allowance for credit losses (in thousands): -----

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies and Significant Management Estimates
Subsubsection Text: The audited consolidated financial statements require management to make estimates and assumptions that may affect reported revenues, results of operations, and net income, as well as the reported amounts of assets and liabilities. Judgments are based on historical experience and other relevant and reasonable assumptions. Actual results may differ from estimates as such estimates may change as additional information is acquired or as circumstances change. A comprehensive disclosure of significant accounting policies can be found in Note 2, Basis of Presentation, Summary _of Significant Accounting Policies and Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements included in the notes to audited_ consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022. The Company believes that the accounting policies that require significant management judgement and estimates are as follows:

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: The Company accounts for business acquisitions that meet the definition of a business combination using the acquisition method of accounting, in accordance with which assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at their respective fair values at the acquisition date. The fair value of the consideration transferred in a business combination, including any contingent consideration, is allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their respective fair values. Goodwill represents excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Acquisitions that do not meet the definition of a business combination are accounted for as asset acquisitions, and the purchase price is allocated to the net assets acquired based on their relative fair values without recognizing goodwill. Significant judgments are used in determining fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Fair value and intangible asset useful life determinations are based on, among other factors, estimates of future expected cash flows, customer attrition rates, royalty cost savings and appropriate discount rates used in computing present values. These judgments may materially impact the estimates used in allocating the purchase price to assets acquired and liabilities assumed, as well as the Company’s current and future operating results. Actual results may vary from these estimates which may result in adjustments to goodwill and acquisition date fair values of assets and liabilities during a measurement period or upon a final determination of asset and liability fair values, whichever occurs first. Adjustments to fair values of assets and liabilities made after the end of the measurement period are recorded within the Company’s operating results.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Title: Goodwill, Intangible Assets and Other Long-Lived Assets
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price in a business combination over the fair value of net tangible and intangible assets acquired. Intangible assets consist of technology, customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames, and backlog. Other long-lived assets generally consist of property and equipment. The Company’s intangible assets, other than backlog and those intangible assets classified as indefinite-lived, as well as the Company’s property and equipment, are depreciated or amortized to expense over their estimated useful lives, or lease term, on a pattern in which the economic benefits are consumed or on a straight-line basis. Intangible assets that are amortized to expense have estimated useful lives that range from eight to twenty-one years. Backlog is amortized, as a reduction of revenue, on a specific identification basis following the recognition of the revenue of the underlying contracts. Amortization of intangible assets charged to cost of revenue and operating expense for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022 was $207.0 million and $206.9 million, respectively. Backlog amortization expense recorded as a reduction of revenue was $6.2 million and $9.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, respectively. Goodwill is not subject to amortization but is tested annually for impairment or more frequently if there are indicators of impairment. The Company performs its annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, or more frequently when events and circumstances occur indicating that the recorded goodwill may be impaired. In assessing qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the Company assesses relevant events and circumstances that may impact the fair value and the carrying amount of a reporting unit. The identification of relevant events and circumstances and how these may impact a reporting unit’s fair value or carrying amount involve significant judgments by management. These judgments include the consideration of macroeconomic conditions, industry and market considerations, cost factors, overall financial performance, events which are specific to the Company, and trends in the fair value of the Company’s common stock. Each factor is assessed to determine whether it impacts the impairment test positively or negatively and the magnitude of any such impact. ----- The Company’s chief operating decision maker is its Chief Executive Officer. The Company, whose management uses consolidated financial information in determining how to allocate resources and assess performance, has determined that it has one reporting unit. The Company performed its annual assessment of goodwill as of September 30, 2023 and 2022 on the single reporting unit and concluded that goodwill had not been impaired. Similar to the evaluation of those long-lived assets that are not amortized, the Company evaluates amortizable intangible assets and other long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value of an asset or asset group may not be recoverable. The Company assesses the recoverability of the assets based on the undiscounted future cash flows the assets are expected to generate and recognizes an impairment loss when estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to result from the use of the assets plus net proceeds expected from disposition of the assets, if any, are less than the carrying value of the assets. If an asset or asset group is deemed to be impaired, the amount of the impairment loss, if any, represents the excess of the asset or asset group’s carrying value compared to its estimated fair value. Each period, the Company also evaluates the estimated remaining useful life of its long-lived intangible assets to determine whether events or changes in circumstances warrant a revision to the remaining period of depreciation or amortization. A considerable amount of judgment is required in performing an impairment analysis, principally in determining discount rates, and financial forecasts. Unanticipated changes in market conditions could have a material impact on the Company’s projected cash flows. Differences in actual cash flows as compared to the projected cash flows, as well as changes in market conditions, could require the Company to record additional impairment losses in the future.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: The guidance states that if an arrangement contains multiple performance obligations, each distinct performance obligation is accounted for separately. Subsequently, the Company recognizes revenue through the application of the following steps: (i) identification of the contract(s) with a customer; (ii) identification of the performance obligations in the contract; (iii) determination of the transaction price; (iv) allocation of the transaction price to performance obligations in the contract; and (v) recognition of revenue when or as the performance obligation is satisfied. The Company’s policy does not permit a right of return. _Non-OEM Revenue Recognition, Unbilled Accounts Receivable, and Deferred Revenue_ The Company’s software licenses are primarily on-premise and fully functional when made available to the customer. As the customer can use and benefit from the license on its own, on-premise software licenses represent distinct performance obligations. Revenue for software licenses is recognized upfront at the point in time when a license key is delivered to a customer, and the customer may use and benefit from the license. These licenses are sold as perpetual or for a fixed term. Perpetual licenses are generally invoiced upon execution of the contract. Term licenses are generally invoiced upfront or on an annual basis over the term of the arrangement, which generally range from one to five years. Any difference between the license revenue recognized and the amount invoiced to the customer is accounted for on the consolidated balance sheets as unbilled accounts receivable. The Company’s maintenance service consists of technical support, bug fixes, and when-and-if available unspecified software upgrades. As these maintenance services are considered to be a series of distinct services that are substantially the same and have the same duration and measure of progress, the Company concludes that they represent one combined performance obligation. Maintenance revenue is therefore recognized ratably over the contract period. Any difference between the maintenance amount invoiced or collected and the maintenance revenue recognized is accounted for on the consolidated balance sheets as deferred revenue. Professional services primarily include consulting and training services. In general, services are distinct performance obligations. Services revenue is generally recognized as the services are delivered to the customer. The Company ----- applies the practical expedient of recognizing revenue upon invoicing for time and materials-based arrangements as the invoiced amount corresponds to the value of the services provided. The Company also sells several SaaS hosted offerings. These SaaS offerings are sold via a subscription-based model. Customers can use hosted software over the contract period without taking possession of it and the services are available to them throughout the entire term, even if they do not use the service. As the services related to this model are indistinct from one another and have the same duration and measure of progress, revenue related to these offerings is recognized ratably over the contract period. SaaS arrangements are generally invoiced on a monthly or quarterly basis over the term of the arrangement. As part of the review over the transaction price, the Company considers whether there are any variable fees, such as usage-based arrangements, or price concessions that may give rise to variable consideration. Revenue related to variable consideration is recorded at the time of the transfer of licenses or services to its customers. Significant judgment is required in estimating standalone selling prices. The Company utilizes observable inputs when they exist, such as for maintenance renewals on historical perpetual license sales, and for SaaS hosted arrangements. The standalone selling prices of certain performance obligations, specifically the standalone selling prices for software licenses, are highly variable. In these instances, the Company estimates a narrow range of standalone selling prices using observable pricing information, such as the Company’s existing price list and historical sales data. When bundled term license and maintenance sales occur, the Company bifurcates the transaction into its two separate performance obligations, and then allocates the transaction value accordingly. The Company’s allocation between the term license and maintenance performance obligations is calculated based upon the observable relationship of the selling price of a standalone maintenance renewal to the related perpetual license fee, which is generally 20% of the net license fee for one year of maintenance. The Company considers using the observable relationship between a perpetual license fee and a standalone maintenance renewal to be appropriate for allocating value within a bundled arrangement because the nature of the respective performance obligations and the rights transferred to the customer are similar. As part of the allocation of the transaction price among performance obligations, the Company considers the presence of any material rights or specified future upgrades that could represent additional performance obligations. The Company did not identify any material right performance obligations in the periods presented. _OEM Revenue Recognition_ Consistent with ASC 606, the Company recognizes royalty revenue to which it is entitled in the period in which it is earned. The Company utilizes customer information and other sources of information to determine the most likely estimate of royalty revenue to be recognized and accrued each period. As a management estimate, the determination of sales based royalty revenue requires significant judgment. In the event of any material difference between the estimate and the actual royalty received, the Company will record an adjustment in the period the revenue was earned.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: The Company’s incremental costs of obtaining a contract which consist of sales commissions, are deferred, and amortized over the period of contract performance or a longer period, generally the expected life of the customer relationship. The expected customer relationship period is determined based on average historical customer relationship periods, including expected renewals. Expected renewal periods are only included in the expected customer relationship period if commission amounts paid upon renewal are not commensurate with amounts paid on the initial contract. Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs the Company incurs to obtain a contract that it would not have incurred if the contract had not been obtained. The Company groups similar contracts based on revenue and customer type and amortizes on a systemic basis over the average contract length or expected customer life.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: ----- Because a portion of the Company’s business is conducted outside of the U.S., there exists the risk of exposure to movements in foreign currency exchange rates. International sales are usually denominated in foreign currencies, and changes in the value of foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar could adversely affect revenue results. However, as most of the Company’s revenue comes from North American entities that operate in U.S. dollars, this is not deemed to be a significant risk. The Company also derives a portion of its revenues from contracts with federal, state, local, and foreign governments and agencies. These customers operate based upon allocated budgets and appropriations. In the event that a government or agency enters into a multi-year contract and does not receive its expected allocated budget, it is possible that the existing contract could be terminated. However, the Company’s standard practice is for any multi-year contract to contain a substantive termination penalty, which provides evidence of enforceable rights and obligations throughout the stated contract term. Therefore, this is not seen to be a significant risk to revenue recognition.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: Deferred income taxes represent differences between the financial statement and tax basis of the Company’s assets and liabilities and for tax net operating loss and credit carry forwards using enacted tax rates expected to be in effect in the years in which the differences are expected to reverse. The Company calculates and recognizes deferred tax assets and liabilities based on expected future tax consequences of these temporary differences. Valuation allowances are calculated for the amount of deferred tax assets that, based on currently available evidence, may not be realized. For uncertain tax positions, the Company records a liability associated with an uncertain tax position if the Company determines that there is not a more likely than not possibility of sustaining such benefit upon audit by the taxing authority based on the technical merits of the position. The Company records a tax benefit of a position as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement. This process involves significant judgments on the part of management.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Title: Research and Development and External Capitalized Software Development Costs
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with ASC 730, the Company expenses costs associated with the development of computer software for external use as incurred prior to the establishment of technological feasibility. The Company has determined that technological feasibility for its software products is reached after all high-risk development issues have been resolved through coding and testing. Costs incurred subsequent to the establishment of technological feasibility and prior to the general release of the products are capitalized. For the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, software costs that were eligible for capitalization have been immaterial, and as a result, no costs have been capitalized.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: The Company capitalizes software development costs in accordance with ASC Topic 350-40, “Internal-Use Software.” The Company capitalizes costs for software to be used internally when entering the application development stage. This occurs when the preliminary project stage is complete, management authorizes and commits to funding the project, and it is feasible that the project will be completed, and the software will perform the intended function. The Company ceases to capitalize costs related to a software project when it enters the post-implementation and operation stage. If different determinations are made with respect to the state of development of a software project, then the amount capitalized and the amount charged to expense for that project could differ materially. Costs capitalized during the application development stage consist of payroll and related costs for employees who are directly associated with, and who devote time directly to, a project to develop software for internal use. The Company also capitalizes the direct costs of materials and services, which generally includes outside contractors, and interest. The Company does not capitalize any general and administrative or overhead costs or costs incurred during the application development stage related to training or data conversion costs. Costs related to upgrades and enhancements to internal-use software, if those upgrades and enhancements result in additional functionality, are capitalized. If upgrades and enhancements do not result in additional functionality, those costs are expensed as incurred. If different determinations are made with respect to whether upgrades or enhancements to software projects would result in ----- additional functionality, then the amount capitalized and the amount charged to expense for that project could differ materially. The Company amortizes capitalized costs with respect to development projects for internal-use software when the software is ready for use. The capitalized software development costs are generally amortized using the straight-line method over a 3-year period. In determining and reassessing the estimated useful life over which the cost incurred for the software should be amortized, the Company considers the effects of obsolescence, technology, competition and other economic factors. As of December 31, 2023 and 2022 capitalized software development costs were $7.0 million and $7.9 million, respectively. Additions, relating to capitalized software development costs, incurred during the years ended December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 were $0.6 million and $5.1 million, respectively.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: The Company determines if an arrangement contains a lease at inception and does not separate lease and non-lease components of an arrangement determined to contain a lease. Operating leases are included in right-of-use (“ROU”) assets, current operating lease liabilities and operating lease liabilities, net of current portion, on the Company’s consolidated balance sheet. Operating leases with a duration of 12 months or less are excluded from ROU assets and operating lease liabilities and related expenses are recorded as incurred. ROU assets represent the Company’s right to use an underlying asset for the lease term and the corresponding lease liabilities represent its obligation to make lease payments arising from the lease. Lease ROU assets and lease liabilities are recognized based on the present value of the future minimum lease payments over the lease term at the lease commencement date. The lease ROU asset includes any initial direct costs incurred and is reduced for tenant incentives. As the Company’s operating leases do not provide an implicit rate, the net present value of future minimum lease payments is determined using the Company’s incremental borrowing rate. To determine the estimated incremental borrowing rate, the Company performs a synthetic credit rating analysis and uses publicly available credit ratings for peer companies based upon the determined synthetic credit rating analysis. The Company estimates the incremental borrowing rate using yields for maturities that are in line with the duration of the lease payments. The Company evaluates the recoverability of the ROU assets for possible impairment in accordance with the longlived assets policy above. Lease expense for minimum lease payments for operating leases is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term. Improvement reimbursements from landlords are amortized through ROU assets on a straight-line basis as a reduction to rent expense over the terms of the corresponding leases.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Text: The Company accounts for asset retirement obligations in accordance with ASC Topic 410, “Asset Retirement and Environmental Obligations”, which applies to certain obligations associated with “leasehold improvements” within leased office facilities. ASC Topic 410 requires that a liability be initially recognized for the estimated fair value of the obligation when it is incurred. The associated asset retirement cost is capitalized as part of the carrying amount of the long-lived asset and depreciated over the remaining life of the underlying asset and the associated liability is accreted to the estimated fair value of the obligation at the settlement date through periodic accretion charges which are generally recorded within “General and administrative” expense in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Income. When the obligation is settled, any difference between the final cost and the recorded amount is recognized as income or loss on settlement in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Income.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Charged to Balance Beginning** **Statement of** **Balance at End of of Period** **Operations** **Deductions (1)** **Period Allowance for credit losses
Subsubsection Title: Foreign Currency Translation and Transaction Accounting
Subsubsection Text: ----- Certain transactions of the Company and its subsidiaries are denominated in currencies other than their functional currency. Foreign currency exchange gain (loss) generated from the settlement and remeasurement of these transactions are recognized in earnings and presented within “Other income (expense), net” in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations. Net foreign currency transaction and remeasurement gain (loss) reflected in “Other income (expenses), net” for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, were $(25.1) million and $11.6 million, respectively. Assets and liabilities of foreign subsidiaries whose functional currency is not the U.S. dollar are translated into U.S. dollars at current exchange rates, while revenues, costs and expenses are translated at average exchange rates during each reporting period. The resulting currency translation gain (loss) are included in “Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)” in the Company’s consolidated balance sheets.

Subsubsection Text: Comprehensive income (loss) represents the change in equity during a period from transactions and other events and circumstances from nonowner sources. Comprehensive income (loss) consists of the net income (loss), foreign currency translation gain (loss), unrealized gain (loss) on derivative contracts, net, and is reported within the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Income (Loss).

Subsubsection Text: See _Note 2, Basis of Presentation, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies and Recently Issued Accounting _Pronouncements in the notes to the audited consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2023_ and 2022 for a full description and discussion of the impact of recent accounting pronouncements.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The Company is exposed to market risk in the ordinary course of business. Market risk represents the risk of loss that may impact financial position due to adverse changes in financial market prices and rates. Market risk exposure is primarily a result of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, customer concentrations and interest rates. The Company does not hold or issue financial instruments for trading purposes.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Approximately 15% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023 were earned in non-U.S. dollar denominated currencies, principally the Euro, British pound, and Australian Dollar. Expenses are generally denominated in the currencies in which operations are located, primarily the U.S. dollar, and to a lesser extent the British pound, Euro, and Indian Rupee. The consolidated results of operations and cash flows are, therefore, subject to fluctuations due to changes in foreign currency exchange rates and may be adversely affected in the future due to changes in foreign exchange rates. The Company may use derivative contracts, including currency swaps, in an effort to mitigate the risk of foreign currency fluctuations relative to the U.S. dollar. In addition, natural hedging exists in several currencies where the Company has revenue and expenses including the four largest exposure currencies: Euro, British pound, Australian dollar and Japanese yen. However, these hedges do not completely eliminate foreign exchange risk and ----- therefore changes in foreign currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and foreign currencies could have a material impact on cash flows and net income (loss).

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Company has unrestricted cash of $239.0 million and $157.8 million at December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, respectively. Cash balances are held at highly rated banks within highly liquid bank deposits and money market funds. The Company does not believe cash deposits have significant risk of default or illiquidity. While the Company believes cash equivalents do not contain excessive risk, the Company cannot provide absolute assurance that in the future cash will not be subject to adverse changes in the credit profile of those banks. In addition, the Company maintains significant amounts of cash at one or more financial institutions that are in excess of federally insured limits. The Company cannot be assured that it will not experience losses on these deposits. The Company is exposed to interest rate risk related to variable-rate debt it has issued or borrowed, including debt under the Existing First Lien Term Loans and the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility. The Company issues long-term debt in either U.S. dollars or foreign currencies based on market conditions at the time of financing. The Company may use interest rate swaps to modify the market risk exposures in connection with the debt to obtain a fixed interest rate. The swap transactions generally involve the exchange of floating for fixed interest payments. However, the Company may choose not to swap floating for fixed interest payments or may terminate a previously executed swap if the Company believes a larger proportion of variable-rate debt would be beneficial.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: A significant portion of revenue is derived from a partnership agreement with IBM, whereby IBM licenses software products on an OEM basis and pays a royalty based on IBM’s recorded license, maintenance and subscription revenue. IBM is responsible for sales and marketing (i.e. “go-to-market”) of IBM-branded products. The Company derives a significant portion of revenue from a long-term strategic partnership with IBM and a termination of this partnership would have a material adverse effect on the Company’s business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Company recognizes that inflationary pressures may have an adverse effect on the Company through higher labor and other operating costs. The Company tries to minimize these impacts through effective control of operating expenses and productivity improvements, as well as price increases to customers. The Company does not believe that inflation has had a material effect on the business, financial condition or results of operations. Nonetheless, if costs were to become subject to significant inflationary pressures, the Company may not be able to fully offset such higher costs. The inability or failure to do so could harm the business, financial condition and results of operations. -----

Section Title: ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following management discussion and analysis of the Company’s financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with the section of this offering memorandum captioned “Business” and the Company’s audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes to those statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. In addition to historical financial information, the following discussion and analysis contains forward- looking statements that involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Actual results and timing of selected events may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of many factors, including those discussed under the sections of this offering memorandum captioned “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.”_

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: - Total revenue was $507.7 million, up 13.2% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. The addition of OT Connectivity, as of February 1, 2023, contributed $37.9 million of revenue. - Total annual recurring revenue, which consists of customer support revenue, was $335.0 million, up 11.2% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. - Gross margin was 90.7% compared to 93.1% in the year ended December 31, 2022, down 2.4%. ----- - Net income was $199.1 million compared to $219.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, down 9.4%. - Operating cash flow was $209.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to $227.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, down 7.9%. - Period to period comparability was impacted by the addition of OT Connectivity to the AMC business, as of February 1, 2023. - On November 28, 2023, OpenText entered into the Acquisition Agreement with Rocket, involving the purchase and sale of the AMC business. Under the Acquisition Agreement, OpenText will receive approximately $2.275 billion in cash at closing.

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impacts of Geopolitical Conflicts and Diplomatic Tensions
Subsubsection Text: The AMC business continues to monitor the geopolitical conflicts and diplomatic tensions around the world, including the Israel-Hamas war. The AMC business continues to operate its Israeli-based business and support the employees of the AMC business in the region. While operations affected by these locations are not material and there is not an expectation that these geopolitical conflicts will have a material adverse effect on the overall business, results of operations or financial condition, it is not possible to predict the broader consequences of these conflicts, including adverse effects on the global economy, on the AMC business and operations as well as those of the AMC business’s customers, partners and third-party service providers.

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The AMC business includes historically a product group of Micro Focus and, beginning February 1, 2023, the OT Connectivity business, a product group of OpenText. OpenText acquired all of the issued and to be issued share capital of Micro Focus on January 31, 2023 as part of the MF Acquisition. For the period starting January 1, 2022 to the date of the MF Acquisition, reference to the “Parent” is to Micro Focus. For the period after the MF Acquisition starting on February 1, 2023, reference to the “Parent” is to OpenText. The audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum have been prepared on a “carve-out” basis. The periods presented were prepared on a standalone basis and have been derived from the accounting records of Micro Focus prior to the MF Acquisition and OpenText following the MF Acquisition. The audited combined carveout financial statements herein have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. Prior to the date of the MF Acquisition, the accounting records and financial information of Micro Focus were prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards, as issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (“IFRS”) and had a different fiscal year end. In preparing the audited combined carveout financial statements, the AMC business presents a fiscal period ended December 31 and has converted any financial information to GAAP. Please see Note 1, Organization and Basis of _Presentation to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum_ for more information on how the audited combined carveout financial statements have been prepared. The AMC business provides market leading mainframe modernization and connectivity software to more than 10,000 customers, enabling them to run mission-critical business applications in hybrid cloud environments. As of December 31, 2023, the AMC business employed a total of 769 individuals. Of the total 769 individuals the AMC business employed as of December 31, 2023, 334 or 43.4% were in the Americas, consisting of countries in North, Central and South America, 391 or 50.9% were in EMEA, consisting of countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, and 44 or 5.7% were in Asia Pacific, primarily consisting of Japan, Australia, China, Korea, the Philippines, Singapore, India and New Zealand. Currently, the AMC business has employees in 29 countries, enabling strong access to multiple talent pools while ensuring reach and proximity to customers. Please see “—Results of Operations” below for the definitions of geographic regions.

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with ASC 606, the AMC business accounts for a customer contract when the AMC business obtains written approval, the contract is committed, the rights of the parties, including the payment terms, are identified, the contract has commercial substance and consideration is probable of collection. Revenue is recognized when, or as, control of a promised product or service is transferred to the AMC business’s customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the AMC business expects to be entitled to in exchange for products and services (at its transaction price). Estimates of variable consideration and the determination of whether to include estimated amounts in the transaction price are based on readily available information, which may include historical, current and forecasted information, taking into consideration the type of customer, the type of transaction and specific facts and circumstances of each arrangement. The AMC business reports revenue net of any revenue-based taxes assessed by governmental authorities that are imposed on and concurrent with specific revenue producing transactions. The AMC business has three revenue streams: customer support, licenses and professional services. -----

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Impairment testing for goodwill is performed annually or more frequently if impairment indicators are present. To determine if goodwill is potentially impaired, the AMC business has the option to perform a qualitative assessment. However, the AMC business may elect to bypass the qualitative assessment and perform a quantitative impairment test even if no indications of a potential impairment exist. The process of estimating the fair value of goodwill is subjective and requires the AMC business to make estimates that may significantly impact the outcome of the analysis. Under the qualitative assessment, the AMC business considers several qualitative factors, including the business enterprise value of the reporting unit and the excess of fair value over carrying value from this test, macroeconomic conditions, industry and market considerations, the recent and projected financial performance of the reporting unit, cost factors, as well as other factors. The AMC business has concluded that there is one reporting unit and assigned the entire balance of goodwill to this reporting unit. On December 31, 2023, and 2022, the AMC business performed its qualitative impairment test for goodwill which indicated that the fair value for the reporting unit exceeded the carrying value, and therefore did not result in a goodwill impairment. Refer to the Goodwill discussion in _Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting _Policies to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for_ additional information.

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The audited combined carveout financial statements have been prepared on a “carve-out” basis and include an allocated share of costs related to Parent corporate functions for certain services provided to the AMC business. Expenses are allocated to the AMC business based on utilization or other metrics deemed reasonable and appropriate by the management of the AMC business (e.g., revenue or headcount). As such, the audited combined carveout financial statements may not include all of the actual expenses that would have been incurred and may not reflect the AMC business’s results of operations, comprehensive income, financial position and cash flows, had it been a standalone company during the periods presented. Actual costs that would have been incurred if the AMC business had been a standalone company would depend on multiple factors, including organization structure and various other strategic decisions. Refer to Note 1, Organization and Basis of Presentation to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for more information.

Section Title: AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Income tax benefit (provision) represents the income tax benefit or expense associated with the AMC business’s operations based on the tax laws of the jurisdictions in which the AMC business operates. Foreign jurisdictions in which the AMC business operates have different statutory tax rates. The AMC business did not operate as a standalone entity in the past and, accordingly, tax losses, receivables and other deferred tax assets included in the audited combined carveout financial statements on a separate return basis may not be available upon separation of the AMC business from Parent. Deferred income taxes are provided for temporary differences in the bases between financial reporting and income tax assets and liabilities. Deferred income taxes are recalculated annually at tax rates in effect for the years in which those tax assets and liabilities are expected to be realized or settled. AMC records valuation allowances to reduce the deferred tax assets to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized. Separately, tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return are measured at the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50 percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement. The AMC business’s effective tax rate fluctuates from period to period due to changes in the mix of income and losses in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences, certain one-time items and changes in tax contingencies. Refer to _Note 10, Income Taxes in the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for further discussion.

While The AMC business does not believe that a change in these estimates is reasonably likely, there can be no assurance that actual results will not differ from these estimates. The AMC business’s accounting policies are described in Note 1, Organization and Basis of Presentation and Note 2, _Summary of Significant Accounting Policies to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere_ in this offering memorandum. AMC BUSINESS’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: ----- The following tables provide a detailed analysis of the AMC business’s results of operations and financial condition. For each of the periods indicated below, the AMC business presents revenues by product type, revenues by major geography, cost of revenues by product type, total gross margin, total operating margin, gross margin by product type and their corresponding percentage of total revenue. The comparability of the AMC business’s operating results for the year ended December 31, 2023 and the year ended December 31, 2022 was impacted by the addition of OT Connectivity to the AMC business on February 1, 2023. Total revenues increased by $59.3 million across all product types in the year ended December 31, 2023, relative to the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to revenue contributions from the addition of OT Connectivity and growth in license revenue of $7.9 million with related customer support revenue and professional service revenue increases of $7.1 million and $6.4 million, respectively. The addition of OT Connectivity contributed $37.9 million to total revenues during the year ended December 31, 2023, of which $26.6 million related to customer support revenues and $11.3 million related to license revenues. Total cost of revenues increased by $16.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, relative to the year ended December 31, 2022, which is comprised of an increase in the AMC business’s direct costs of $11.6 million, allocated shared corporate costs of $3.8 million, and additional direct costs of $1.2 million as a result of the MF Acquisition and addition of that business. Of the total $16.6 million increase, $15.7 million was driven by labor-related and consulting costs. The increase in labor-related costs were caused by a reorganization of the go-to-market operations of Micro Focus during the second half of 2022, which resulted in an increase in the dedicated AMC business customer support headcount, an investment in increasing the professional service consultants in the AMC business, and the MF Acquisition and addition of that business. The consulting costs increase was driven by an increase in outsourcing costs following a transition from internal to outsourced support for first line customer support implemented in the second half of 2021 and the first half of 2022 as well as increased use of contracting resources to support professional service projects during 2023. Total operating expenses increased by $60.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, relative to the year ended December 31, 2022, which is comprised of additional research and development, sales and marketing, and general and administrative allocated shared corporate costs of $29.0 million, the AMC business’s direct expenses of $26.0 million and $5.7 million of direct costs associated with the addition of OT Connectivity.

Subsubsection Title: Revenues, Cost of Revenues and Gross Margin by Product Type Customer Support
Subsubsection Text: Customer support revenues consist of revenues from customer support and maintenance agreements. These agreements allow customers to receive technical support, enhancements and upgrades to new versions of software products when available. Customer support revenues are generated from support and maintenance relating to current year sales of software products and from the renewal of existing maintenance agreements for software licenses sold in prior periods. Therefore, changes in customer support revenues do not always correlate directly to the changes in license revenues from period to period. The terms of support and maintenance agreements are typically twelve months, and are renewable, generally on an annual basis, at the option of the customer. The management of the AMC business reviews customer support renewal rates on a quarterly basis, and use these rates as a method of monitoring customer service performance. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the customer support renewal rate for the AMC business was approximately 91.8%, compared to approximately 90.8% for the year ended December 31, 2022. For OT Connectivity, customer support renewal rate was 95.8% for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to the 94.5% for the year ended December 31, 2022. Cost of customer support revenues is comprised primarily of technical support personnel and related costs, as well as contract labor and third-party consulting costs.

Subsubsection Text: Professional service revenues consist primarily of revenues from technical services and training services. Technical services may include installation, customization, implementation or consulting services. Professional services are typically performed after the purchase of new software licenses. Professional service revenues can vary from period to period based on the type of engagements as well as those implementations that are assumed by the AMC business’s partner network. Cost of professional service revenues consists primarily of the costs of providing integration, configuration and training with respect to the AMC business’s various software products. The most significant components of these costs are personnel-related expenses and third-party subcontracting.

The increase was primarily driven by an incremental license revenues from the addition of OT Connectivity of $11.3 million over the comparative period with the remaining $7.9 million increase caused by strong performance within the Host Connectivity and MF Enterprise Suite portfolios of the AMC business. The increase in Host Connectivity was a result of new license wins and reversed a decline in 2022 which had returned license revenue to the historic level of 2021. The increase in MF Enterprise Suite was a consequence of investments made in sales and engineering resources during 2022 becoming fully effective during 2023. Geographically, the overall change was attributable to an increase in Americas of $14.3 million, an increase in EMEA of $4.1 million and an increase in Asia Pacific of $0.8 million. During the year ended December 31, 2023, the AMC business had 48 license contracts greater than $0.5 million, of which 21 contracts were greater than $1.0 million, contributing $67.2 million of license revenues. This was compared to 43 license contracts greater than $0.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2022, of which 22 contracts were greater than $1.0 million, contributing $59.3 million of license revenues. ----- Cost of license revenues increased by $0.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. Overall, the gross margin percentage on license revenues remained stable for the year ended December 31, 2023 at 99.0%.

The increase was primarily driven by growth in the MF Enterprise Suite within the AMC business over the comparative period. This increase was the result of additional investments in consulting resources, which were made during 2022 but became fully effective and revenue generating in 2023. Geographically, the overall change was attributable to an increase in Americas of $2.6 million, an increase in EMEA of $3.7 million and an increase in Asia Pacific of $0.1 million. Cost of professional service revenues increased by $3.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. This was primarily due to an increase in labor-related costs of $4.3 million caused by an increase in the number consultants employed by the AMC business during 2022 resulting from a planned investment in the AMC business’s consulting resources as well as a change to bonus based incentives, which are included in labor-related costs, rather than commission-based incentives during the second half of 2023. This led to an offsetting decrease of commissions costs of $1.3 million over the comparative period, along with an immaterial increase to consulting costs. Overall, the gross margin percentage on professional service revenues increased to 22.7% from 8.9% as a result of the investment in the recruitment, onboarding and training of consulting resources during 2022, which were then fully utilized in revenue generating activity in 2023.
