Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: We have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Rocket Software, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the "Company"), which comprise the consolidated balance sheets as of December 31, 2023 and 2022, and the related consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive income (loss), of stockholders’ equity and of cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2023, including the related notes (collectively referred to as the "consolidated financial statements"). In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2023 and 2022, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2023 in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: We conducted our audit in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America (US GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditors' Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be independent of the Company and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audit. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: As discussed in Note 2 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company changed the manner in which it accounts for leases in 2022. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Responsibilities of Management for the Consolidated Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Company's ability to continue as a going concern for one year after the date the consolidated financial statements are available to be issued.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Auditors' Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditors' report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with US GAAS will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the ----- override of internal control. Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the consolidated financial statements. In performing an audit in accordance with US GAAS, we: - Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. - Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements. - Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is expressed. - Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements. - Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Company's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time. We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control-related matters that we identified during the audit.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Management is responsible for the other information included in the annual report. The other information, which is not presented herein, comprises management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations, quantitative and qualitative disclosures about market risk, foreign currency exchange risk, interest rate risk, client relationship with IBM, and inflation, but does not include the consolidated financial statements and our auditors' report thereon. Our opinion on the consolidated financial statements does not cover the other information, and we do not express an opinion or any form of assurance thereon. In connection with our audit of the consolidated financial statements, our responsibility is to read the other information and consider whether a material inconsistency exists between the other information and the consolidated financial statements or the other information otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If, based on the work performed, we conclude that an uncorrected material misstatement of the other information exists, we are required to describe it in our report. /s/ PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP Boston, Massachusetts March 23, 2024 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Rocket Software, Inc. Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements 1.** **Nature of Business
Subsubsection Text: Rocket Software, Inc. and subsidiaries (the “Company”) builds and services enterprise software products and solutions that help corporations, government agencies and other organizations operate, optimize and modernize their mission-critical IT infrastructure. The Company’s strategy is to lead in its existing product markets by: (a) growing the installed base of its software through the license of its products to original equipment manufacturer (“OEM”) partners, independent software vendor (“ISV”) partners, reseller partners and enterprise customers through branded direct sales; (b) retaining the loyalty of those customers by providing solutions, features, and flexibility through its service and support businesses; and (c) expand its market share by acquiring and integrating businesses with similar technology, customers, platforms, and sales channels. The Company has its primary operations in the United States, Europe, Australia, China, India and Japan. The Company is subject to risks common to growing technology-based companies, including dependence on key personnel, rapid technological change, competition from substitute products and larger companies, dependence upon relationships with OEMs and ISVs and the need for continued market acceptance of the Company’s products and services.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: 2.** **Basis of Presentation, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies and Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements Principles of Consolidation
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries. All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. Significant items with reported amounts based on estimates including, but not limited to revenue, accounts receivable, unbilled accounts receivable, goodwill and intangible assets, right-of-use assets and lease obligations, purchase price allocations, contingent liabilities, deferred revenue, accrued expenses, derivative assets and liabilities, other liabilities and deferred income taxes.

Subsection Title: Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Credit Losses
Subsubsection Text: Accounts receivable are stated at the amount management expects to collect from outstanding balances. Management reviews accounts receivable on a periodic basis to determine if any receivables will potentially be uncollectible. The Company reserves for receivables that are determined to be uncollectible, if any, in its allowance for credit losses. The allowance is based upon the credit worthiness of customers, historical experience, the age of the receivable and current market and economic conditions. After all attempts to collect a receivable have failed, the receivable is written off against the allowance. The following is a roll-forward of the Company’s allowance for credit losses (in thousands):

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Company accounts for business acquisitions that meet the definition of a business combination using the acquisition method of accounting, in accordance with which assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at their respective fair values at the acquisition date. The fair value of the consideration transferred in a business combination, including any contingent consideration, is allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their respective fair values. Goodwill represents excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Acquisitions that do not meet the definition of a business combination are accounted for as asset acquisitions, and the purchase price is allocated to the net assets acquired based on their relative fair values without recognizing goodwill. Significant judgments are used in determining fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Fair value and intangible asset useful life determinations are based on, among other factors, estimates of future expected cash flows, customer attrition rates, royalty cost savings, and appropriate discount rates used in computing present values. These judgments may materially impact the estimates used in allocating the purchase price to assets acquired and liabilities assumed, as well as the Company’s current and future operating results. Actual results may vary from these estimates which may result in adjustments to goodwill and acquisition date fair values of assets and liabilities during a measurement period or upon a final determination of asset and liability fair values, whichever occurs first. Adjustments to fair values of assets and liabilities made after the end of the measurement period are recorded within the Company’s operating results.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Goodwill, Intangible Assets and Other Long-Lived Assets
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price in a business combination over the fair value of net tangible and intangible assets acquired. Intangible assets consist of technology, customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames, and backlog. Other long-lived assets generally consist of property and equipment. ----- The Company’s intangible assets, other than backlog and those intangible assets classified as indefinite-lived, as well as the Company’s property and equipment, are depreciated or amortized to expense over their estimated useful lives, or lease term, on a pattern in which the economic benefits are consumed or on a straight-line basis. Intangible assets that are amortized to expense have estimated useful lives that range from eight to twenty-one years. Backlog is amortized, as a reduction of revenue, on a specific identification basis following the recognition of the revenue of the underlying contracts. Amortization of intangible assets charged to cost of revenue and operating expense for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021 was $207.0 million, $206.9 million and $169.2 million, respectively. Backlog amortization expense recorded as a reduction of revenue was $6.2 million, $9.1 million and $7.8 million for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. Goodwill is not subject to amortization but is tested annually for impairment or more frequently if there are indicators of impairment. The Company performs its annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, or more frequently when events and circumstances occur indicating that the recorded goodwill may be impaired. In assessing qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the Company assesses relevant events and circumstances that may impact the fair value and the carrying amount of a reporting unit. The identification of relevant events and circumstances and how these may impact a reporting unit’s fair value or carrying amount involve significant judgments by management. These judgments include the consideration of macroeconomic conditions, industry and market considerations, cost factors, overall financial performance, events which are specific to the Company, and trends in the fair value of the Company’s common stock. Each factor is assessed to determine whether it impacts the impairment test positively or negatively, and the magnitude of any such impact. The Company’s chief operating decision maker is its Chief Executive Officer. The Company, whose management uses consolidated financial information in determining how to allocate resources and assess performance, has determined that it has one reporting unit. The Company performed its annual assessment of goodwill as of September 30, 2023, 2022 and 2021 on the single reporting unit and concluded that goodwill had not been impaired. Similar to the evaluation of those long-lived assets that are not amortized, the Company evaluates amortizable intangible assets and other long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value of an asset or asset group may not be recoverable. The Company assesses the recoverability of the assets based on the undiscounted future cash flows the assets are expected to generate and recognizes an impairment loss when estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to result from the use of the assets plus net proceeds expected from disposition of the assets, if any, are less than the carrying value of the assets. If an asset or asset group is deemed to be impaired, the amount of the impairment loss, if any, represents the excess of the asset or asset group’s carrying value compared to its estimated fair value. Each period, the Company also evaluates the estimated remaining useful life of its long-lived intangible assets to determine whether events or changes in circumstances warrant a revision to the remaining period of depreciation or amortization. A considerable amount of judgment is required in performing an impairment analysis, principally in determining discount rates, and financial forecasts. Unanticipated changes in market conditions could have a material impact on the Company’s projected cash flows. Differences in actual cash flows as compared to the projected cash flows, as well as changes in market conditions, could require the Company to record additional impairment losses in the future.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Non-OEM Revenue Recognition, Unbilled Accounts Receivable, and Deferred Revenue
Subsubsection Text: The Company’s software licenses are primarily on-premise and fully functional when made available to the customer. As the customer can use and benefit from the license on its own, on-premise software licenses represent distinct performance obligations. Revenue for software licenses is recognized upfront at the point in time when a license key is delivered to a customer, and the customer may use and benefit from the license. These licenses are sold as perpetual or for a fixed term. Perpetual licenses are generally invoiced upon execution of the contract Term licenses are generally invoiced upfront or on an annual basis over the term of the arrangement, which generally range from one to five years. Any difference between the license revenue recognized and the amount invoiced to the customer is accounted for on the Consolidated Balance Sheets as unbilled accounts receivable. The Company’s maintenance service consists of technical support, bug fixes, and when-and-if available unspecified software upgrades. As these maintenance services are considered to be a series of distinct services that are substantially the same and have the same duration and measure of progress, the Company concludes that they represent one combined performance obligation. Maintenance revenue is therefore recognized ratably over the contract period. Any difference between the maintenance amount invoiced or collected and the maintenance revenue recognized is accounted for on the Consolidated Balance Sheets as deferred revenue. Professional services primarily include consulting and training services. In general, services are distinct performance obligations. Services revenue is generally recognized as the services are delivered to the customer. The Company applies the practical expedient of recognizing revenue upon invoicing for time and materials-based arrangements as the invoiced amount corresponds to the value of the services provided. The Company also sells several Software-as-a-Service (“SaaS”) hosted offerings. These SaaS hosted offerings are sold via a subscription-based model. Customers can use hosted software over the contract period without taking possession of it and the services are available to them throughout the entire term, even if they do not use the service. As the services related to this model are indistinct from one another and have the same duration and measure of progress, revenue related to these offerings is recognized ratably over the contract period. SaaS arrangements are generally invoiced on a monthly or quarterly basis over the term of the arrangement. As part of the review over the transaction price, the Company considers whether there are any variable fees, such as usage-based arrangements, or price concessions that may give rise to variable consideration. Revenue related to variable consideration is recorded at the time of the transfer of licenses or services to its customers. Significant judgment is required in estimating standalone selling prices. The Company utilizes observable inputs when they exist, such as for maintenance renewals on historical perpetual license sales, and for SaaS hosted arrangements. The standalone selling prices of certain performance obligations, specifically the standalone selling prices for software licenses, are highly variable. In these instances, the Company estimates a narrow range of standalone selling prices using observable pricing information, such as the Company’s existing price list and historical sales data. When bundled term license and maintenance sales occur, the Company bifurcates the transaction into its two separate performance obligations, and then allocates the transaction value accordingly. The Company’s allocation between the term license and maintenance performance obligations is calculated based upon the observable relationship of the selling price of a standalone maintenance renewal to the related perpetual license fee, which is generally 20% of the net license fee for one year of maintenance. The Company considers using the observable relationship between a perpetual license fee and a standalone maintenance renewal to be appropriate for allocating value within a bundled arrangement because the nature of the respective performance obligations and the rights transferred to the customer are similar. As part of the allocation of the transaction price among performance obligations, the Company considers the presence of any material rights or specified future upgrades that could represent additional performance obligations. ----- The Company did not identify any material right performance obligations in the periods presented.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Consistent with ASC 606, the Company recognizes royalty revenue to which it is entitled in the period in which it is earned. The Company utilizes customer information and other sources of information to determine the most likely estimate of royalty revenue to be recognized and accrued each period. As a management estimate, the determination of sales based royalty revenue requires significant judgment. In the event of any material difference between the estimate and the actual royalty received, the Company will record an adjustment in the period the revenue was earned.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The guidance provides that if an arrangement contains multiple performance obligations, each distinct performance obligation is accounted for separately. Revenue is subsequently recognized through the application of the following steps: (i) identification of the contract(s) with a customer; (ii) identification of the performance obligations in the contract; (iii) determination of the transaction price; (iv) allocation of the transaction price to performance obligations in the contract; and (v) recognition of revenue when or as the performance obligation is satisfied. The Company’s policy does not allow for a right of return. -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Company’s incremental costs of obtaining a contract which consist of sales commissions, are deferred, and amortized over the period of contract performance or a longer period, generally the expected life of the customer relationship. The expected customer relationship period is determined based on average historical customer relationship periods, including expected renewals. Expected renewal periods are only included in the expected customer relationship period if commission amounts paid upon renewal are not commensurate with amounts paid on the initial contract. Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs the Company incurs to obtain a contract that it would not have incurred if the contract had not been obtained. The Company groups similar contracts based on revenue and customer type and amortizes on a systemic basis over the average contract length or expected customer life.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Because a portion of the Company’s business is conducted outside of the U.S., there exists the risk of exposure to movements in foreign currency exchange rates. International sales are usually denominated in foreign currencies, and changes in the value of foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar could adversely affect revenue results. However, as most of the Company’s revenue comes from North American entities that operate in USD, this is not deemed to be a significant risk. The Company also derives a portion of its revenues from contracts with federal, state, local, and foreign governments and agencies. These customers operate based upon allocated budgets and appropriations. In the event that a government or agency enters into a multi-year contract and does not receive its expected allocated budget, it is possible that the existing contract could be terminated. However, the Company’s standard practice is for any multiyear contract to contain a substantive termination penalty, which provides evidence of enforceable rights and obligations throughout the stated contract term. Therefore, this is not seen to be a significant risk to revenue recognition.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Deferred income taxes are provided for differences between the financial statement and tax basis of the Company’s assets and liabilities and for tax net operating loss and credit carry forwards using enacted tax rates expected to be in effect in the years in which the differences are expected to reverse. Valuation allowances are provided for the amount of deferred tax assets that, based on currently available evidence, may not be realized. Under the guidance in ASC 740 for uncertain tax positions, the Company records a liability associated with an uncertain tax position if the Company determines that there is not a more likely than not possibility of sustaining such benefit upon audit by the taxing authority based on the technical merits of the position. The Company records a tax benefit of a position as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Research and Development and External Capitalized Software Development Costs
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with ASC 730, the Company expenses costs associated with the development of computer software for external use as incurred prior to the establishment of technological feasibility. The Company has determined that technological feasibility for its software products is reached after all high-risk development issues have been resolved through coding and testing. Costs incurred subsequent to the establishment of technological feasibility and ----- prior to the general release of the products are capitalized. For the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, software costs that were eligible for capitalization have been immaterial, and as a result, no costs have been capitalized.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Company capitalizes software development costs in accordance with ASC Topic 350-40, “Internal-Use Software.” The Company capitalizes costs for software to be used internally when entering the application development stage. This occurs when the preliminary project stage is complete, management authorizes and commits to funding the project, and it is feasible that the project will be completed, and the software will perform the intended function. The Company ceases to capitalize costs related to a software project when it enters the postimplementation and operation stage. If different determinations are made with respect to the state of development of a software project, then the amount capitalized and the amount charged to expense for that project could differ materially. Costs capitalized during the application development stage consist of payroll and related costs for employees who are directly associated with, and who devote time directly to, a project to develop software for internal use. The Company also capitalizes the direct costs of materials and services, which generally includes outside contractors, and interest. The Company does not capitalize any general and administrative or overhead costs or costs incurred during the application development stage related to training or data conversion costs. Costs related to upgrades and enhancements to internal-use software, if those upgrades and enhancements result in additional functionality, are capitalized. If upgrades and enhancements do not result in additional functionality, those costs are expensed as incurred. If different determinations are made with respect to whether upgrades or enhancements to software projects would result in additional functionality, then the amount capitalized and the amount charged to expense for that project could differ materially. The Company amortizes capitalized costs with respect to development projects for internal-use software when the software is ready for use. The capitalized software development costs are generally amortized using the straight-line method over a 3-year period. In determining and reassessing the estimated useful life over which the cost incurred for the software should be amortized, the Company considers the effects of obsolescence, technology, competition and other economic factors. As of December 31, 2023 and 2022 capitalized software development costs were $7.0 million and $7.9 million, respectively. Additions relating to capitalized software development costs incurred during the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021 were $0.6 million, $5.1 million and $3.7 million, respectively.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Company accounts for asset retirement obligations in accordance with ASC Topic 410, “Asset Retirement and Environmental Obligations” (Topic 410), which applies to certain obligations associated with “leasehold improvements” within leased office facilities. Topic 410 requires that a liability be initially recognized for the estimated fair value of the obligation when it is incurred. The associated asset retirement cost is capitalized as part of the carrying amount of the long-lived asset and depreciated over the remaining life of the underlying asset and the associated liability is accreted to the estimated fair value of the obligation at the settlement date through periodic accretion charges which are generally recorded within "General and administrative" expense in Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Income. When the obligation is settled, any difference between the final cost and the recorded amount is recognized as income or loss on settlement in Consolidated Statements of Income.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Foreign Currency Translation and Transaction Accounting
Subsubsection Text: Certain transactions of the Company and its subsidiaries are denominated in currencies other than their functional currency. Foreign currency exchange gain (loss) generated from the settlement and remeasurement of these transactions are recognized in earnings and presented within “Other income (expense), net” in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations. Net foreign currency transaction and remeasurement gain (loss) reflected in “Other income (expenses), net” for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, were $(25.1) million, $11.6 ----- million and $9.9 million, respectively. Assets and liabilities of foreign subsidiaries whose functional currency is not the U.S. dollar are translated into U.S. dollars at current exchange rates, while revenues, costs and expenses are translated at average exchange rates during each reporting period. The resulting currency translation gain (loss) are included in "Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)" in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Comprehensive income (loss) represents the change in equity during a period from transactions and other events and circumstances from nonowner sources. Comprehensive income (loss) consists of the net income (loss), foreign currency translation gain (loss), unrealized gain (loss) on derivative contracts, net, and is reported within the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Income (Loss).

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Other income (expense) includes interest income, gains and losses on long-lived asset disposals, gains and losses on derivative instruments not designated for hedging, gains on investments, losses on early retirement of debt, and realized and unrealized foreign currency transaction gains and losses.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Recently issued accounting pronouncements not yet adopted
Subsubsection Text: In December 2023, the FASB issued ASU 2023-09, Improvements to Income Tax Disclosures, enhancing income tax disclosure requirements by requiring specified categories and greater disaggregation within the rate reconciliation table, disclosure of income taxes paid by jurisdiction, and providing clarification on uncertain tax positions and related financial statement impacts. The new standard will be effective for the Company on January 1, 2025, with early adoption permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adoption of the standard on its consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In March 2020, the FASB issued ASU No. 2020-04, “Reference Rate Reform” under ASC _848, intended to provide temporary optional expedients and exceptions to U.S. GAAP guidance on contract modifications and hedge accounting to ease the financial reporting burdens related to the expected market transition from the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) and other interbank offered rates to alternative reference rates. This guidance was effective beginning on March 12, 2020, and the Company may apply the amendments prospectively to contract modifications made or relationships entered into or evaluated through December 31, 2022. In December 2022, the FASB issued ASU No. 2022-06 which deferred the sunset date of Topic 848 from December 31, 2022, to December 31, 2024. The Company adopted this ASU in 2023, with no material impact on its consolidated financial statements. In June 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-13, Financial Instruments - Credit Losses (Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments ("ASU 2016-13"), which requires measurement and recognition of expected credit losses for financial assets measured at amortized cost, including accounts receivable, upon initial recognition of that financial asset using a forward looking expected loss model, rather than an incurred loss model. Credit losses relating to available-for-sale debt securities should be recorded through an allowance for credit losses when the fair value is below the amortized cost of the asset, removing the concept of "other-than-temporary" impairments. The Company adopted this standard effective January 1, 2023. The adoption of this standard did not have a material effect on the Company’s consolidated financial statements. In February 2016, the FASB established Topic 842, Leases, by issuing Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2016-02, which requires lessees to recognize leases on-balance sheet and disclose key information about leasing ----- arrangements. Topic 842 was subsequently amended by ASU No. 2018-01, Land Easement Practical Expedient for Transition to Topic 842; ASU No. 2018-10, Codification Improvements to Topic 842, Leases; and ASU No. 201811, Targeted Improvements. The new standard establishes a right-of-use model (ROU) that requires a lessee to recognize a ROU asset and lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with a term longer than 12 months. Leases will be classified as finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern and classification of expense recognition in the income statement. The Company adopted ASC 842 effective January 1, 2022 using the required modified retrospective approach and utilizing the effective date as its date of initial application. As a result, prior periods are presented in accordance with the previous guidance in ASC 840. ASC 842 provides several optional practical expedients in transition. The Company applied the package of practical expedients to leases that commenced prior to the effective date whereby the following are not required to be reassessed: (i) whether any expired or existing contracts are or contain leases; (ii) the lease classification for any expired or existing leases; and (iii) the treatment of initial direct costs for existing leases. The Company elected the short-term lease expedient for all leases that qualified based on a lease term of 12 months or less, and consequently a right-of-use asset or lease liability was not recognized for short term leases. Upon its adoption of ASC 842, the Company recorded lease liabilities and their corresponding right-of-use assets based on the present value of lease payments over the remaining lease term. The incremental borrowing rate (IBR) at January 1, 2022 was used to calculate the present value of the Company’s lease portfolio as of that date. The adoption of ASC 842 resulted in the recognition of operating lease liabilities of $29 million and right-of-use assets of $26 million on the Company’s balance sheet as of January 1, 2022, as well as a corresponding deferred tax asset and deferred tax liability of $7 million and $6 million, respectively. The adoption of ASC 842 did not have a material impact on the Company’s statements of operations and comprehensive loss or statements of cash flows. In December 2019, the FASB issued ASU No. 2019-12 (“ASU 2019-12”), Simplifying the Accounting for Income Taxes, as part of its initiative to reduce complexity in accounting standards. For non-public entities, this guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021, and for interim periods within annual periods beginning after December 15, 2022, with early adoption permitted. The Company adopted this ASU on January 1, 2022, with no material impact on its consolidated financial statements. On October 28, 2021, the FASB issued ASU 2021-08 - Business Combinations (Topic 805): Accounting for _Contract Assets and Contract Liabilities from Contracts with Customers (“ASU 2021-08”). ASU 2021-08 requires_ an acquirer in a business combination to recognize and measure deferred revenue from acquired contracts using the revenue recognition guidance in Accounting Standards Codification Topic 606, rather than the prior requirement to record deferred revenue at fair value. Generally, this new guidance will result in the acquirer recognizing contract assets and contract liabilities at the same amounts recorded by the acquiree. ASU 2021-08 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022 and interim periods within those fiscal years. Early adoption is permitted including adoption in an interim period. The amendments should be applied prospectively; however, an entity that elects to early adopt in an interim period should apply the amendments to all business combinations that occurred during the fiscal year that includes that interim period. During the fourth quarter of 2021, the Company elected to early adopt ASU 2021-08 on a retrospective basis, effective on January 1, 2021. The adoption of ASU 2021-08 effective as of January 1, 2021 had the following impact on the Company’s results for the year ended December 31, 2021:

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Revision of Prior Period Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: During the preparation of the 2023 consolidated financial statements, the Company identified certain errors in the previously issued 2022 and 2021 consolidated financial statements related to the accounting for the fair value of hedges recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income and the calculation of the interest expense deduction within the tax provision. With respect to hedge accounting, the Company did not appropriately record the deferred tax impact of the fair value of the hedges that were recognized in accumulated other comprehensive income. With respect to the other error, the Company did not appropriately reflect certain items in the calculation of the annual limitation of the interest expense deduction. These errors resulted in an overstatement of income taxes receivable of $3.9 million, an understatement of income taxes payable of $1.3 million, an understatement of deferred tax liabilities of $13.6 million and an overstatement of accumulated other comprehensive income of $18.8 million as of December 31, 2022. These errors also resulted in an overstatement of income taxes receivable of $2.9 million, an overstatement of deferred tax liabilities of $9.7 million and an understatement of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) of $6.8 million as of December 31, 2021. These errors also resulted in an understatement of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) of $17.3 million as of December 31, 2020. In the consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive income/(loss), the errors also resulted in an overstatement of $25.6 million to each of the unrealized (loss) gain on derivative contracts, net, other comprehensive (loss) income and comprehensive (loss) income for the years ended December 31, 2022, and an overstatement of $10.5 million to each of the unrealized (loss) gain on derivative contracts, net, other comprehensive (loss) income and comprehensive (loss) income for the years ended December 31, 2021. These errors did not have any impact on the previously reported net loss for both periods. In the consolidated statements of cash flows, the errors resulted in an understatement of deferred income taxes of $2.3 million, an overstatement of the change in prepaid expenses and other current assets of $1.0 million and an understatement of the change in income taxes payable of $1.3 million within cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2022. The errors also resulted in an understatement of deferred income taxes of $2.9 million and an understatement of the change in income taxes payable of $2.9 million within cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2021. There was no impact on the previously reported net cash flows from operating activities, investing activities or financing activities for both periods. After giving consideration to these errors, the Company has concluded that they were not material to any previously issued consolidated financial statements. The 2022 and 2021 consolidated financial statements and the related footnotes have been revised to correct for these errors.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In 2018, the Company entered into a credit facility with a syndicate of lenders that was comprised of (i) a first lien term loan in an aggregate principal amount of $1,300.0 million (the “First Lien Term Loan”), (ii) the conversion of $825.0 million in borrowings under the First Lien Term Loan into borrowings of $470.0 million (the “Dollar Term Loan”) and 300.0 million Euro (the “Euro Term Loan”) via a syndicate of lenders, each with a maturity date of November 2025. On October 5, 2023, the Company amended its credit agreements to extend the maturity date of its First Lien debt from November 2025 to November 2028, decrease the combined USD term loan under the First Lien Term Loan and the Dollar Term Loan to an aggregate principal of approximately $1,407.5 million (the “New Dollar Term Loan), and increase the Euro term loan from €300.0 to €575.0 million (the “New Euro Term Loan” and, together with the New Dollar Term Loan, the “Existing First Lien Term Loan”). The Company paid $30.1 million of original issue discount which was recorded net within Long-term debt and is being amortized over the term of the agreement to interest expense. The Company paid $10.0 million of third-party fees, of which $0.8 million, related to new lenders in the syndication, were recorded net within Long-term debt and are being amortized over the term of the agreement to interest expense and $9.2 million, related to existing lenders in the syndication, were expensed and recorded within general and administrative in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The Company expensed $2.6 million for loss of extinguishment of debt related to lenders exiting the syndication and recorded within other (expense) income, net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. Under the terms of the New Dollar Term Loan, the principal amount is paid in quarterly installments equal to 1.0% of the original principal amount per annum until the final maturity date, and monthly floating interest rate payments are made based on the one-month Term SOFR rate, plus a margin of 4.75%. Under the terms of the New Euro Term Loan, the Company will make monthly floating interest rate payments based on the one-month EURIBOR rate (with a minimum of 0.00%) plus a margin of 4.75%. The Company has an option to adjust the Term SOFR and EURIBOR interest periods from the one-month rate to another period under the agreement. The remaining principal payment, after installment payments, is due upon maturity. The First Lien includes a revolving loan facility (“Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility”) of up to $152.9 million with an interest rate, at the Company’s election, the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.25% or the alternative base rate plus 2.25%, with step-downs to, (i) the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.125% or the alternative base rate plus 2.125%, as applicable, and (ii) the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.00% or the alternative base rate plus 2.00%, as applicable, in each case based on achieving certain First Lien Net Leverage Ratios, as defined in the credit ----- agreement governing the Existing First Lien Term Loan and the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility. The maturity date of the First Lien Revolver is November 28, 2026. Net availability under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility totaled $151.7 million at December 31, 2023 after giving effect to $1.2 million of letters of credit issued thereunder. The credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Term Loan contains a financial covenant which requires a maximum Net Leverage Ratio of 7.70 to 1.00 if, on the last day of any quarter, the amount of borrowing under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility is greater than 35% of the total revolving commitment. As of December 31, 2023, the Company was in compliance with all financial covenants under the New Credit Facility.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: As of August 16, 2019, the Company assumed a new debt (“RSD Debt”) in connection with the 2019 acquisition of Sixon Holding SA. Per the RSD credit facilities agreement dated September 19, 2018, RSD Debt consists of facility A, a CHF 17.5 million senior amortizing term loan facility and facility B, a CHF 17.5 million senior non-amortizing term loan facility. The debt has multiple maturity dates through 2024. The amortizing term loan facility is subject to mandatory repayments of CHF 3.2 million, payable annually on December 31st through 2022, with a final payment of CHF 3.2 million due on March 28, 2024. The non-amortizing term loan facility has a maturity date of September 28, 2024.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On February 2, 2021, in connection with the Company’s acquisition of Uniface (“Uniface”), the Company issued $575.0 million of 6.5% senior notes (the “Senior Notes”). The Company used the net proceeds from the offering of the Senior Notes, together with cash on hand, (i) to finance and consummate the Uniface acquisition, (ii) to repay in full the outstanding indebtedness and accrued interest under the Second Lien, (iii) to pay down all outstanding borrowings under the First Lien Revolver (without reducing any commitments thereunder), (iv) to pay transaction expenses and fees in connection with each of the foregoing and (v) to the extent of any remaining proceeds, for other general corporate purposes, which may include future acquisitions and strategic investment opportunities. The Senior Notes are unsecured and bear interest at a rate of 6.5% per year, and interest on the notes accrue from February 2, 2021 and will be payable semi-annually, in cash in arrears, on February 15 and August 15 of each year, commencing August 15, 2021. The Senior Notes have a maturity date of February 15, 2029. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On November 28, 2023, the Company entered into a Purchase Agreement (the “Agreement”) with Open Text Corporation (“OpenText”), pursuant to which OpenText has agreed to divest, directly and indirectly through certain subsidiaries, its Application Modernization and Connectivity business (the “AMC Business”) and the Company has agreed to purchase the same and generally assume certain liabilities related to the AMC Business, as set forth in the Agreement, for an all-cash purchase price of $2.275 billion, before taxes, fees and other adjustments (such transactions collectively, the “AMC Transaction”). The closing of the AMC Transaction is expected to be consummated (the “Closing”) subsequent to the year ended December 31, 2023, subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. The Agreement contains customary representations, warranties and covenants for a transaction of this type, including a covenant providing for each of the parties to use reasonable efforts to cause the AMC Transaction to be consummated. Subject to certain limitations, the Company and OpenText have also agreed to indemnify each other for certain liabilities that have been specifically allocated between the parties. During the period between the execution of the Agreement and the Closing, the Company and OpenText will also enter into a Transition Services Agreement, pursuant to which OpenText and its affiliates will provide support for a period of up to 24 months from the Closing to the Company in connection with the AMC Business. The Company incurred acquisition-related costs of $15.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2023. These costs are presented within general and administrative expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The Company incurred $0.9 million of costs that will be capitalized as deferred debt issuance costs upon the closing of debt expected to be raised in connection with the acquisition. These are currently presented within other assets, net in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On May 20, 2021 (the “Closing Date”), Rocket Software, Inc. through its wholly owned subsidiary, Avengers Merger Sub, Inc. acquired 100% interests in ASG Everglades Holdings, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiaries, ASG Technologies Holdings, Inc., ASG Technologies Group, Inc. (collectively, “ASG” or the “Acquiree”) for a total purchase price of $828.0 million, net of cash acquired of $28.4 million. The Company paid $856.4 million in cash at the time of the closing. This acquisition expands the ability of Rocket to develop and modernize mission-critical enterprise applications that deliver legendary business outcomes and solutions to customers. In accordance with the FASB’s ASC 805 Business Combinations, Rocket was determined to be the accounting acquirer. As such, Rocket applied the acquisition method of accounting with respect to the identifiable assets and liabilities of ASG, which have been measured at estimated fair value as of the date of the business combination. ASG’s assets and liabilities were measured at estimated fair values primarily using Level 3 inputs. Estimates of fair value represent management’s best estimate of assumptions about future events and uncertainties, including significant judgements related to future cash flows, discount rates, competitive trends, margin and revenue growth assumptions including royalty rates and customer attrition rates, market comparables and others. Inputs used were generally obtained from historical data supplemented by current and anticipated market conditions and growth rates. Since the Closing Date, the Company has made measurement period adjustments to reflect facts and circumstances in existence as of the Closing Date. These adjustments primarily included an adjustment to conform ASG’s revenue recognition policy of allocating contract consideration to performance obligations to Rocket’s policy, and an adjustment to write off an IPR&D intangible asset that was initially measured. The table below incorporates the impact of the measurement period adjustments to date as well as the effect on the adoption of ASU 2021-08. The following table summarizes the allocation of purchase price to the identifiable assets and liabilities assumed by Rocket with the excess of purchase price over the fair value of ASG’s net assets recorded as goodwill. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In April 2023, the Company purchased 3,339,700 ordinary shares of Software AG at an aggregate purchase price of $110.2 million or €29.88 per share (“direct shares”). In addition, the Company entered into certain equity swap transactions with respect to 4,075,100 ordinary shares of Software AG (“indirect shares”) and paid $67.3 million in connection with the collateral relating to such equity swap transactions. The transactions were funded with cash on hand and $30.0 million of borrowings under the Company’s revolving credit facility. On May 9, 2023, the Company made a non-binding offer to purchase all of the ordinary shares of Software AG at an initial offer price of €34 per share, which offer price would be increased to €36 per share if certain of Software AG existing shareholders would agree to support the offer and sell their ordinary shares to the Company. On June 19, 2023, the Company withdrew its non-binding offer and through its UK subsidiary, entered into an agreement with Mosel Bidco SE, a holding company controlled by funds managed or advised by Silver Lake, for the sale and transfer of its entire stake of 7,414,800 shares or approximately 10.02% in Software AG for €32.00 per share. On June 29, 2023, the Company paid $132.7 million to the equity swap counterparty and received physical delivery of the indirect shares relating to the equity swap and together with the direct shares, sold 100% of its stake in Software AG to Mosel Bidco SE, resulting in net proceeds of $258.6 million and a gain of $15.7 million. The gain consisted of a $6.5 million gain on the sale of the direct shares, net of commissions of $0.1 million, and a $9.2 million gain on the settlement of the equity swap. The collateral of $67.3 million relating to the equity swap was also returned in the second quarter of 2023. A portion of the proceeds were used to pay down in full the outstanding balance on the revolver as of June 30, 2023. In the second quarter of 2023, the Company also recorded dividend income of $0.3 million, interest income on collateral of $0.6 million, and $1.0 million of margin interest expense, which along with the gain is included in Other income (expense), net within the Consolidated Statements of Operations. In addition, the Company recorded approximately $2.5 million in acquisition-related costs in the second quarter of 2023, which is included in General and administrative expenses within the Consolidated Statements of Operations. -----

Deferred income taxes reflect the effect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities recognized for financial reporting purposes and the amounts recognized for tax purposes. Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if, based on the weight of available positive and negative evidence, it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized. On January 1, 2022, certain provisions of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (“TCJA”) became effective with significant impact to the Company. Adjusted taxable income (“ATI”), on which a 30% interest expense limitation is based is no longer adjusted for depreciation, amortization and depletion, resulting in lower ATI and greater interest expense disallowance. Additionally, research and experimental expenditures (“R&E”) are no longer immediately ----- deductible for tax purposes in the year incurred, and instead, must be capitalized and amortized over a period of 5 years (for research conducted within the U.S.) or 15 years (for research conducted in foreign jurisdictions). As of December 31, 2023, the Company has approximately $5.4 million of U.S. federal net operating loss carryforwards, $305.6 million of U.S. federal interest expense carryforward, $6.2 million of U.S. state net operating loss carryforwards and $9.1 million of U.S. state tax credit carryforwards. The U.S. federal interest expense carryforward and certain of the U.S. state credit carryforwards may be carried forward indefinitely. The remaining carryforwards expire at various points through 2040, if not utilized. The Company also has net operating losses in the United Kingdom of $5.2 million, in Germany of $20.3 million, in Brazil of $2.6 million and in Singapore of $2.7 million which can all be carried forward indefinitely. Additionally, the Company has a minimum alternate tax (“MAT”) credit in India in the amount of $0.9 million which can be carried forward indefinitely. The Company has recorded valuation allowances against the portions of the U.S. interest expense carryforwards, U.S. state tax credit carryforwards, and United Kingdom net operating losses that more likely than not will not be utilized. The United Kingdom net operating loss carryforwards are subject to certain acquisition-related utilization limitations, which provide uncertainty with respect to their future realization. The total valuation allowance increased by $17.0 million during 2023, primarily related to the U.S. interest expense carryforwards and the increase in U.S. states tax credit carryforwards. The Company indefinitely reinvests the foreign earnings of its subsidiaries in Australia and Switzerland and has specific and measurable plans to reinvest those earnings. The Company has determined that the deferred tax liability on the future repatriation of $7.7 million of unremitted earnings in Switzerland that are indefinitely reinvested is not material as of December 31, 2023. Accounting for income taxes requires a two-step approach to recognizing and measuring uncertain tax positions. The first step is to evaluate the tax position for recognition by determining if, based on the technical merits, it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon audit, including resolution of related appeals or litigation processes, if any. The second step is to measure the tax benefit as the largest amount that is more than 50% likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement. The Company reevaluates these uncertain tax positions on an annual basis, based on factors including, but not limited to, changes in facts or circumstances, changes in tax law, effectively settled issues under audit and new audit activity. Any changes in these factors could result in the recognition of a tax benefit or an additional charge to the tax provision. The Company had gross unrecognized tax benefits, excluding interest and penalties, of $22.8 million, $25.6 million and $19.7 million as of December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. The year-over-year decrease relates primarily to the expiration of the statute of limitations on certain unrecognized tax benefits, partially offset by the increase associated with the uncertainty related to the sourcing of certain revenue for state tax purposes. The amount of unrecognized tax benefits that, if recognized, would result in a reduction of the Company’s effective tax rate is $13.6 million as of December 31, 2023. The following is a tabular reconciliation of beginning and ending balances of unrecognized tax benefits (in thousands): ----- The Company accounts for interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions as part of its provision for income taxes. As of December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021 total accrued interest and penalties were $1.9 million, $1.7 million and $1.4 million, respectively. To the extent that tax attributes would be available to offset any tax associated with uncertain tax positions upon assessment by a taxing authority, the liabilities for such uncertain tax positions are recorded as reductions of the deferred tax assets for such attributes. Otherwise, the liabilities for uncertain tax positions, including interest and penalties, are included in other long-term liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheet. The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, as well as various U.S. state and foreign jurisdictions. With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, U.S. state, or foreign examinations by tax authorities for years before 2019. However, carryforward attributes from prior years may still be adjusted upon examination by tax authorities if they are used in an open year. Although the Company believes its tax estimates are appropriate, the final determination of tax examinations could result in favorable or unfavorable changes in its estimates. The Company anticipates the expiration of certain statutes of limitations during 2024 that could result in a decrease in its unrecognized tax benefits between $6.5 million and $7.5 million.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Company is party to various leases for property, office space, equipment, and automobiles. The Company determines if an arrangement contains a lease at inception or upon modification of a contract and classifies each lease as either an operating or finance lease. The Company only reassesses lease classification subsequent to the commencement date if the contract is modified. Finance and operating lease assets represent the Company’s right to use an underlying asset as lessee for the lease term, and lease obligations represent the Company’s obligation to ----- make lease payments arising from the lease. These assets and obligations are recognized at the lease commencement date based on the present value of lease payments, net of incentives, over the lease term. Generally, the Company's lease contracts do not provide a readily determinable implicit rate and, therefore, the Company uses its estimated incremental borrowing rate as of the lease commencement date in determining the present value of lease payments. The lease asset also reflects any lease payments made, initial direct costs incurred, and lease incentives received prior to commencement date. The Company’s lease terms include periods under options to extend or terminate the lease when it is reasonably certain that those options will be exercised. Certain lease agreements contain variable payments, which are expensed as incurred and not included in the lease assets and liabilities. These variable payments include insurance, taxes, payments tied to a consumer price index or other such indices, and payments for maintenance and utilities. For all leases, the Company does not separate lease components and non-lease components. Leases with an initial expected term of 12 months or less are not recorded in the Consolidated Balance Sheets and the related lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On June 21, 2019, the board of directors of BCPE Rover Holdings, Inc. (“BCPE Holdings”) ratified and approved the adoption of the 2018 Stock Option Plan (the “Option Plan”), which authorizes BCPE Holdings to grant awards to members of the board, officers and employees of the Company in BCPE Holdings, which is the indirect parent of the Company. The Option Plan was adopted to incentive grant recipients to promote the long-term growth and profitability of the Company and its affiliates. In accordance with the Option Plan, BCPE Holdings also authorized 550,000 shares of the Class B Common Stock of BCPE Holdings (“Class B Stock”) to be granted in the form of nonqualified stock options. Stock compensation expense was $1.6 million, $2.8 million and $1.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. The number of options granted to purchase Class B Stock were 39,737 and 95,026 for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, respectively. Options granted under the Option Plan are be exercisable only to the extent that they are vested. Option grants are divided into two vesting tranches: “Time-Vesting Options” and “Performance-Vesting Options,” with a 50% allocation to each tranche. Time-Vesting Options vest over a five-year period following the vesting start date (which is typically the grant date). Twenty percent of the Time-Vesting Options will vest on each anniversary of the grant date until all Time-Vested Options are fully-vested. All Time-Vesting options provide for accelerated vesting upon a change of control and 100% will vest upon a change in control; however, an initial public offering will not accelerate vesting. Performance-Vesting Options are subject to time and performance vesting and will only be fully vested when they have met both time and performance vesting requirements. Performance-Vesting Options will time vest in the same manner as Time-Vesting Options. Performance-Vesting Options will performance vest as follows: 50% vesting if funds associated with Bain Capital (“Sponsor”) Returns (as defined in the Option Plan) through the measurement date are at least two times the initial Sponsor investment and 100% vesting if Sponsor Returns are at least three times the initial Sponsor investment. An IPO may result in the accelerated vesting of PerformanceVesting Options. As of December 31, 2023, the grant date fair value of the Time-Vesting and Performance-Vesting Options were $11.8 million and $10.6 million, respectively. Remaining unrecognized compensation expense was $3.1 million for the unvested Time Vesting Options as of December 31, 2023 and is expected to be recognized over the related weighted average period of 2 years. The Company recorded compensation expense for the Time Vesting Options of $1.6 million, $2.8 million and $1.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively, which was included in general and administrative, cost of sales, research & development, and sales and marketing expenses. As of December 31, 2023, the Company has not deemed the achievement of the vesting criteria of the PerformanceVesting Options to be probable, and therefore there has been no compensation expense recorded for these performance-based vesting awards to date. Total unrecognized compensation expense was $10.6 million for the unvested Performance-Vesting Options as of December 31, 2023. The Company will reassess the probability of achieving investor return targets at the end of each reporting period. The Company is a private company and lacks certain company-specific historical and implied volatility information. Therefore, it estimates its expected option volatility based on the historical volatility of a publicly traded group of peer companies. The expected term of the Company’s equity interests is based on management’s estimate of time until a potential liquidity event. The risk-free rate is determined by reference to the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant of the award for the time periods approximately equal to the expected term of the award. Expected dividend yield is zero based on the fact that the Company does not expect to pay cash dividends. Subsubsection Text: The Company sponsors an employee retirement plan under Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code (the “401(k) Plan”). The 401(k) Plan allows employees to make pretax contributions up to the maximum allowable amount set by the Internal Revenue Service. Under the 401(k) Plan, the Company may match a portion of the employee contribution up to a defined maximum and may make an additional, discretionary, profit-sharing contribution. The Company made matching contributions of $3.5 million of the total $8.5 million in employee retirement plans, $3.3 million of the total $6.9 million and $2.8 million of the total $5.4 million to the 401(k) Plan for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: 14.** **Concentration of Credit Risk and Significant Customers
Subsubsection Text: Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk include cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash, billed and unbilled accounts receivable, and derivative instruments. At December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, the Company had cash and cash equivalent balances at certain financial institutions in excess of federally insured limits. However, the Company maintains its cash and cash equivalents with accredited financial institutions and does not believe that it is subject to unusual credit risk beyond the normal credit risk associated with commercial banking relationships. Concentrated credit risk with respect to accounts receivable is limited to large, creditworthy customers and partners. The Company has not experienced material credit losses related to receivables from individual partners, customers or groups of customers in any specific industry or geographic area. The Company manages credit risk with counterparties on derivative instruments by trading among several counterparties and by trading with accredited financial institutions. The Company has no significant offbalance-sheet concentration of credit risk. As of December 31, 2023, one strategic partner accounted for 40% of the Company’s combined billed and unbilled accounts receivable. As of December 31, 2022, one strategic partner accounted for 39% and one customer accounted for 7% of the Company’s combined billed and unbilled and accounts receivable. No other customer or partner accounted for more than 3% of the Company’s combined billed and unbilled accounts receivable for any period presented. We derive a significant portion of our revenue from a long-term strategic partnership with IBM. For the fiscal years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, we generated 40%, 38% and 35%, respectively, of our total revenue from this partnership. No other customer or partner accounted for more than 7% of our total revenue during these periods.

Subsubsection Title: Risk Management Objective of Using Derivatives
Subsubsection Text: The Company enters into derivative instruments to manage risks related to its business operations and economic conditions. Derivative financial instruments are used to manage exposures to interest rate and foreign exchange risk in order to reduce the risk that the Company’s cash flows, earnings, and investment in foreign subsidiaries will be adversely affected. ----- As of December 31, 2023, the Company had the following derivatives:

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Cash Flow Hedges of Interest Rate Risk
Subsubsection Text: The Company’s objectives in using interest rate derivatives are to add stability to interest expense and to manage its exposure to interest rate movements. To accomplish this objective, the Company primarily uses interest rate products such as swaps and caps as part of its interest rate risk management strategy. Interest rate swaps designated as cash flow hedges involve the receipt of variable amounts from a counterparty in exchange for the Company making fixed-rate payments over the life of the agreements without exchange of the underlying notional amount. Interest rate caps designated as cash flow hedges involve the receipt of variable amounts from a counterparty if interest rates rise above the strike rate on the contract in exchange for a premium. During 2022 and 2023, such derivatives were used to hedge the variable cash flows associated with existing variable-rate debt. These contracts have maturities of 23 months or less as of December 31, 2023. For derivatives designated and that qualify as cash flow hedges of interest rate risk, the unrealized gain or loss on the derivative is recorded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (“AOCI”) and subsequently reclassified into interest expense in the same periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings. As of December 31, 2023, the net accumulated income deferred in AOCI on cash flow hedges before tax effect was $21.8 million, $18.6 million of which the Company expects will be reclassified to interest expense within the next 12 months.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Company designated a fixed-to-fixed cross-currency swap agreement as a net investment hedge. The Company’s risk management objective and strategy for the net investment hedge transaction is to protect a designated monetary amount of the Company’s net investment in Rocket Software UK International, a GBPfunctional-currency consolidated subsidiary, against the risk of changes in the GBP-USD exchange rate. The Company’s cross-currency swap involves the receipt of functional-currency-fixed-rate amounts from a counterparty in exchange for the Company making foreign-currency fixed-rate payments over the life of the agreement. The cross-currency swap also involves a final (at maturity) exchange of the functional-currency principal amount(s) for the foreign-currency principal amount(s). For derivatives designated as net investment hedges, the unrealized gain or loss is reported in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income as part of the cumulative translation adjustment. Amounts are reclassified out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income into earnings when the hedged net investment is either sold or substantially liquidated. -----

Changes in the fair value of derivatives not designated in hedging relationships are recorded directly in Other income, net.

Subsubsection Text: The guidance in ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, defines fair value, and establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). The three levels of the fair value hierarchy are described below: Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. Level 2 Inputs other than Level 1 that are observable, either directly or indirectly, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities. Level 3 Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets and liabilities. To the extent that valuation is based on models or inputs that are less observable or unobservable in the market, the determination of fair value requires more judgment. Accordingly, the degree of judgment exercised by the Company in determining fair value is greatest for instruments categorized in Level 3. A financial instrument’s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement. Fair value is a market-based measure considered from the perspective of a market participant rather than an entityspecific measure. Therefore, even when market assumptions are not readily available, the Company’s own assumptions are set to reflect those that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability at the measurement date. The Company uses prices and inputs that are current as of the measurement date, including during periods of market dislocation. In periods of market dislocation, the observability of prices and inputs may be reduced for many instruments. This condition could cause an instrument to be reclassified from Level 1 to Level 2 or Level 2 to Level 3. Subsubsection Text: In December 2023, the Company announced the decision to exit its operations in China as a broader initiative to colocate many of the application modernization products at the Company’s development centers located in Vilnius, Lithuania; Pune, India; and Bentonville, Arkansas. The cost of the China exit plan is estimated to be $16.0 million to $18.0 million and consists primarily of employeerelated costs. The Company incurred $7.3 million of expense related to the program in the fourth quarter of 2023, which are included in General and administrative expenses within the Consolidated Statement of Operations. The plan is expected to be complete in the first half of 2025. In July 2023, management approved a plan to reduce its global workforce by approximately 5%. The plan was substantially completed during the three-month period ended September 30, 2023 with costs incurred of $6.4 million, which are included in General and administrative expenses within the Consolidated Statement of Operations. Restructuring plan liabilities are included in Accrued expenses in the Consolidated Balance Sheets. The total cost of the plan was $57.2 million and was completed in the second quarter of 2023. The plan included restructuring-related costs such as employee severance, other employee-related costs, asset impairments, and facility ----- exit costs as well as consulting fees relating to the integration which are recorded in General and administrative expenses within the Consolidated Statement of Operations.
