Subsubsection Text: The Board of Directors Open Text Corporation: _Opinion_ We have audited the combined carveout financial statements of the AMC Business of Open Text Corporation (the AMC Business), which comprise the combined carveout balance sheets as of December 31, 2023 and 2022, the related combined carveout statements of income and comprehensive income, changes in equity, and cash flows for the years then ended, and the related notes to the combined carveout financial statements. In our opinion, the accompanying combined carveout financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the AMC Business as of December 31, 2023 and 2022, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. _Basis for Opinion_ We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Combined Carveout Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be independent of the AMC Business and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion. _Responsibilities of Management for the Combined Carveout Financial Statements_ Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the combined carveout financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, and for the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of combined carveout financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the combined carveout financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the AMC Business’ ability to continue as a going concern for one year after the date that the combined carveout financial statements are issued. ----- _Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Combined Carveout Financial Statements_ Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the combined carveout financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditors’ report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the combined carveout financial statements. In performing an audit in accordance with GAAS, we: - Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. - Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the combined carveout financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the combined carveout financial statements. - Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the AMC Business’ internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is expressed. - Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the combined carveout financial statements. - Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the AMC Business’ ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time. We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control related matters that we identified during the audit. /s/ KPMG LLP Toronto, Canada March 28, 2024 -----

Subsection Title: AMC Business of Open Text Corporation Notes to Combined Carveout Financial Statements (Amounts in thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise noted)
Subsubsection Text: (Dollars in thousands, except where otherwise noted) ###### Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation _Organization_ The AMC Business (the “Business”), of Open Text Corporation (“OpenText”) includes Application Modernization & Connectivity (“AMC”), historically a product group of Micro Focus International Limited, formerly known as Micro Focus International PLC, (“Micro Focus”) and, beginning February 1, 2023, the OpenText Connectivity business (“OT Connectivity”), a product group of OpenText. OpenText acquired all of the issued and to be issued share capital of Micro Focus on January 31, 2023 (“the Acquisition”). The contribution of OT Connectivity is reflected as a transfer in of the OT Connectivity business in the Combined Carveout Statements of Cash Flows, which represents OT Connectivity's net assets as of the Acquisition date, which is mainly comprised of goodwill and net working capital, including accounts receivable and deferred revenues, and deferred tax assets. For the periods starting January 1, 2022 to the date of the Acquisition, reference to the “Parent” in these Combined Carveout Financial Statements is to Micro Focus. For the period after the Acquisition starting on February 1, 2023, reference to the “Parent” in these Combined Carveout Financial Statements is to Open Text. The Business provides market leading mainframe modernization and connectivity software and its solutions are categorized in the following areas: MF Common Business Oriented Language (“COBOL”), Host Connectivity, MF Enterprise Suite, Mainframe Application Development Life Cycle Management (“ADLM”) and Common Object Request Broker Architecture (“CORBA”). The MF COBOL product portfolio enables customers to develop, maintain, and deploy applications using COBOL across different platforms. Host Connectivity, which is the portfolio containing OT Connectivity includes products for enterprises to manage host access across desktop, web and mobile devices, manage mainframe access with enhanced security and integrate mainframe and host systems. MF Enterprise Suite is a mainframe application which helps enterprises move mainframe workloads to the cloud, therefore, reducing costs and increasing agility. Mainframe ADLM is comprised of products that offer enhanced mainframe applications which help shorten app delivery cycles, including faster development and deployment, strengthen security via multifactor authentication and data encryption, and optimize user interface experiences to boost productivity. The CORBA product facilitates distributed computing by providing a standard process for software components to request services and exchange data in a networked environment. On November 28, 2023, OpenText entered into a definitive agreement with Rocket Software, Inc. (“Rocket”), a Bain Capital portfolio company, involving the purchase and sale of the Business (the “Transaction”). Under the Transaction, OpenText will receive approximately $2.275 billion in cash at closing. Upon completion of the Transaction, the Business will be transferred by OpenText to a newly formed wholly owned subsidiary of Rocket. _Basis of Presentation_ The Combined Carveout Financial Statements prior to the date of the Acquisition represent the financial information of AMC’s portion of the Business. Beginning February 1, 2023, the Combined Carveout Financial Statements represent the financial information combining AMC’s portion and OT Connectivity’s portion of the Business, which is the date on which both were under common control of OpenText. The Combined Carveout Financial Statements have been prepared on a “carve-out” basis. The periods presented were prepared on a standalone basis and have been derived from the accounting records of Micro Focus prior to the Acquisition and OpenText following the Acquisition. The Combined Carveout Financial Statements herein have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (“U.S. GAAP”). Prior to the date of the Acquisition, the accounting records and financial information of Micro Focus were prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standard (“IFRS”) and had a different fiscal year end. In preparing the Combined Carveout Financial Statements, the Business has aligned to a fiscal period ended December 31 and have converted any financial information to U.S. GAAP. ----- The historical results of income, comprehensive income, financial position and cash flows presented in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements may not be indicative of what they would have been had the Business actually been an independent standalone entity, nor are they necessarily indicative of the Business’ future results of income, comprehensive income, financial position and cash flows. It is not practicable to estimate actual costs that would have been incurred had the Business been a separate, standalone company. Financial information presented in the financial statements and notes herein is presented in thousands of U.S dollars, unless otherwise stated. The Combined Carveout Financial Statements include all revenues and costs directly attributable to the Business and an allocation of expenses related to certain support services received from the Parent, such as, human resources, legal, finance, central and shared technology, and various other Parent corporate functions and overhead. These expenses have been attributed to the Business based on direct usage or benefit where identifiable, with the remainder allocated using a reasonable methodology primarily on the basis of revenue or headcount. Management considers these allocations to be a reasonable reflection of the utilization of services or the benefits received. Corporate expense allocations were recorded in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income within the following captions: For the Year Ended December 31, 2023 2022 Cost of revenues $ 19,198 $ 15,462 Research and development expense 11,462 287 Sales and marketing expense 38,401 32,131 General and administrative expense 46,993 35,434 Other (income) expense, net (735) 3,262

Subsubsection Text: The accompanying Combined Carveout Financial Statements include the accounts of the Business on a combined basis. The Business also includes subsidiaries over which a direct or indirect legal or effective control exists and for which the Business is deemed to direct the significant activities and has the obligation to absorb the losses or benefits of the entities. The Business does not constitute a solely dedicated group of legal entities.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires the Business to make certain estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements. These estimates, judgments and assumptions are evaluated on an ongoing basis. Estimates are based on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable at that time, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from those estimates. In particular, key estimates, judgments and assumptions include those related to: (i) revenue recognition, (ii) accounting for income taxes, (iii) accounting for allowance for doubtful accounts, (iv) accounting for goodwill and testing for impairment, (v) useful lives for property and equipment and intangible assets, and (vi) the allocation of shared corporate costs. ###### Note 2. Accounting Policies and Recent Accounting Pronouncements

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Combined Carveout Financial Statements include assets and liabilities specifically attributable to the Business. Parent’s net investment, included within Equity, represents the Parent’s investment in the Business including accumulated net earnings attributable to Parent, the net effect of transactions with Parent and cost allocations from the Parent that were not historically allocated to the Business. All intercompany transactions and balances within the Business have been eliminated. Transactions with the Parent and the Business are deemed to have been settled immediately through Net parent investment and are reflected in Equity as Net transfers to/from Parent. Cash has not been assigned to the Business for any of the periods presented because those cash balances are not directly attributable to the Business as a centralized approach was used by the Parent to manage cash and financing of its operations. These arrangements are not reflective of the manner in which the Business would have financed its operations had it been a standalone company separate from the Parent during the periods presented. Cash pooling, related interest, and intercompany arrangements are excluded from the asset and liability balances in the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets. These amounts have instead been reported within Net parent investment, as a component of Equity. The Parent’s long-term debt and related interest expense have not been attributed to the Business for any of the periods presented because the Parent’s borrowings are neither directly attributable to the Business nor is the Business the legal obligor of such borrowings. The Income tax provisions in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income have been calculated as if the Business filed a separate tax return and was operating as a standalone company. Therefore, tax expense and items of current and deferred taxes may not be reflective of the Business’s actual tax balances. The Business operates as one reportable segment based upon the information used by the chief operating decision maker (“CODM”) in evaluating the performance of the Business and allocating resources and capital. -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Credit Losses
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with ASC Topic 326, “Financial Instruments – Credit Losses” (Topic 326), the Business recognizes expected credit losses for accounts receivable and contract assets based on lifetime expected losses. Loss allowances are recognized using a collective assessment for accounts receivable, including contract assets, with similar risk characteristics based on historical credit loss experience, adjusted for forward-looking factors specific to the debtors and economic environment. The Business continues to maintain an allowance for 100% of all accounts deemed to be uncollectible. Customer creditworthiness is evaluated prior to order fulfillment and based on evaluations; the Business adjusts the credit limit to the respective customer. In addition to these evaluations, the Business conducts on-going credit evaluations of customers’ payment history and current creditworthiness. To date, the actual losses have been within the Business’ expectations. No single customer accounted for more than 10% of the accounts receivable balance as of December 31, 2023 and 2022.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Property and equipment are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value and shown net of depreciation which is computed on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the related assets. Gains and losses on asset disposals are taken into income in the year of disposition. Fully depreciated property and equipment are retired from the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets when they are no longer in use. Please see the “Impairment of long-lived assets” section below for policy on property and equipment impairments. The following represents the estimated useful lives of property and equipment as of December 31, 2023 and 2022: Computer hardware 1 to 5 years Computer software 3 to 7 years

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Business enters into operating leases for certain facilities for use in the ordinary course of business. Leases with an initial term of 12 months or less are not recorded on the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets. ----- In accordance with ASC Topic 842, “Leases” (Topic 842), the Business accounts for a contract as a lease when the Business has the right to direct the use of the asset for a period of time while obtaining substantially all of the asset’s economic benefits. The Business determines the initial classification and measurement of the right of use (ROU) assets and lease liabilities at the lease commencement date and thereafter if modified. ROU assets represent the right to control the underlying assets under lease, and the lease liability is the Business’ obligation to make the lease payments related to the underlying assets under lease, over the contractual term. ROU assets and lease liabilities are recognized on the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets based on the present value of future minimum lease payments to be made over the lease term. When available, the Business will use the rate implicit in the lease to discount lease payments to present value. However, real estate leases generally do not provide a readily determinable implicit rate, therefore, the Business must estimate the incremental borrowing rate to discount the lease payments. The Business estimates the incremental borrowing rate based on a collateralized basis with similar terms and payments, in the economic environment where the leased asset is located. The ROU asset equals the lease liability, adjusted for any initial direct costs, prepaid rent and lease incentives on initial recognition. Fixed lease costs are included in the recognition of ROU assets and lease liabilities. Variable lease costs are not included in the measurement of the lease liability. These variable lease payments are recognized in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income in the period in which the obligation for those payments is incurred. Lease expense for minimum lease payments continues to be recognized in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income on a straight-line basis over the lease term. The Business has not elected the practical expedient to combine lease and non-lease components in the determination of lease costs for facility leases. The lease liability includes lease payments related to options to extend or renew the lease term only if it is reasonably certain the Business will exercise those options. The leases typically do not contain any material residual value guarantees or restrictive covenants.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price in a business combination over the fair value of net tangible and intangible assets acquired. The carrying amount of goodwill is periodically reviewed for impairment (at a minimum annually) and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of this asset may not be recoverable. The Business performs a qualitative assessment to test the reporting unit’s goodwill for impairment. Based on the qualitative assessment, if the Business determines that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not (i.e., a likelihood of more than 50 percent) to be less than its carrying amount, the quantitative assessment of the impairment test is performed. In the quantitative assessment, the Business compares the fair value of the reporting unit to its carrying value. If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, goodwill is not considered impaired and the Business is not required to perform further testing. If the carrying value of the net assets of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, then an impairment loss equal to the difference, but not exceeding the total carrying value of goodwill allocated to the reporting unit, would be recorded. The Business has concluded that there is one reporting unit and assigned the entire balance of goodwill to this reporting unit. The annual impairment analysis of goodwill was performed as of December 31, 2023 and 2022. The qualitative assessment indicated that there were no indications of impairment and therefore there was no impairment of goodwill required to be recorded for the years ended December 31, 2023 or 2022.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Acquired intangibles consist of acquired technology and customer relationships, inclusive of tradenames associated with various acquisitions. Acquired technology is initially recorded at fair value based on the present value of the estimated net future incomeproducing capabilities of software products acquired in acquisitions. The Business amortizes acquired technology over its estimated useful life on a straight-line basis. Customer relationships and tradenames represent relationships that the Business has with customers of the acquired companies and are either based upon contractual or legal rights or are considered separable; that is, capable of being separated from the acquired entity and ----- being sold, transferred, licensed, rented or exchanged. These customer relationships and tradenames are initially recorded at their fair value based on the present value of expected future cash flows. The Business amortizes technology, tradenames, and customer relationship on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives. Technology 4 to 10 years Tradenames 10 years Customer relationships 7 to 10 years The Business continually evaluates the remaining estimated useful life of the intangible assets being amortized to determine whether events and circumstances warrant a revision to the remaining period of amortization.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Business accounts for the impairment and disposition of long-lived assets in accordance with ASC Topic 360, “Property, Plant, and Equipment” (Topic 360). The Business tests long-lived assets or asset groups, such as property and equipment, ROU assets and definite lived intangible assets, for recoverability when events or changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amount may not be recoverable. Circumstances which could trigger a review include but are not limited to: significant adverse changes in the business climate or legal factors; current period cash flow or operating losses combined with a history of losses or a forecast of continuing losses associated with the use of the asset; and a current expectation that the asset will more likely than not be sold or disposed of before the end of its estimated useful life. Recoverability is assessed based on comparing the carrying amount of the asset to the aggregate pre-tax undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposal of the asset or asset group. Impairment is recognized when the carrying amount is not recoverable and exceeds the fair value of the asset or asset group. The impairment loss, if any, is measured as the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds fair value, which for this purpose is based upon the discounted projected future cash flows of the asset or asset group. The Business has not recorded any impairment charges for long-lived assets during 2023 or 2022.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with ASC Topic 606, “Revenue from Contracts with Customers” (Topic 606), the Business accounts for a customer contract when the Business obtains written approval, the contract is committed, the rights of the parties, including the payment terms, are identified, the contract has commercial substance and consideration is probable of collection. Revenue is recognized when, or as, control of a promised product or service is transferred to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the Business expects to be entitled to in exchange for products and services (at its transaction price). Estimates of variable consideration and the determination of whether to include estimated amounts in the transaction price are based on readily available information, which may include historical, current and forecasted information, taking into consideration the type of customer, the type of transaction and specific facts and circumstances of each arrangement. The Business reports revenue net of any revenue-based taxes assessed by governmental authorities that are imposed on and concurrent with specific revenue producing transactions. The Business has three primary revenue streams: customer support, license, and professional service.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Customer support revenue is associated with perpetual and term license. As customer support is not critical to the customer’s ability to derive benefit from its right to use software, customer support is considered as a distinct performance obligation when sold together in a bundled arrangement along with the software. Customer support consists primarily of technical support and the provision of unspecified updates and upgrades on a when-and-ifavailable basis. Customer support for perpetual licenses is renewable, generally on an annual basis, at the option of the customer. Customer support for term licenses is renewable concurrently with such licenses for the same duration of time. Payments for customer ----- support are generally made at the inception of the contract term or in installments over the term of the maintenance period. The customer support team is ready to provide these maintenance services, as needed, to the customer during the contract term. As the elements of customer support are delivered concurrently and have the same pattern of transfer, customer support is accounted for as a single performance obligation. The customer benefits evenly throughout the contract period from the guarantee that the customer support resources and personnel will be available to them, and that any unspecified upgrades or unspecified future products developed by the Business will be made available. Revenue for customer support is recognized ratably over the contract period based on the start and end dates of the maintenance term, in line with how the Business believes services are provided.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: License revenue can be broadly categorized as perpetual licenses and term licenses, all of which are deployed on the customer’s premises.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Perpetual licenses: The Business sells perpetual licenses which provide customers the right to use software for an indefinite period
Subsubsection Text: of time in exchange for a one-time license fee, which is generally paid at contract inception. Perpetual licenses provide a right to use IP that is functional in nature and have significant stand-alone functionality. Accordingly, for perpetual licenses of functional IP, revenue is recognized at the point-in-time when control has been transferred to the customer, which normally occurs once software activation keys have been made available for download.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: Professional services, when offered along with software licenses, consist primarily of technical and training services. Technical services may include installation, customization, implementation or consulting services. Training services may include access to online modules or delivering a training package customized to the customer’s needs. At the customer’s discretion, the Business may offer one, all, or a mix of these services. Payment for professional services is generally a fixed fee or is a fee based on time and materials. Professional services can be arranged in the same contract as the software license or in a separate contract. As professional services do not significantly change the functionality of the license and customers can benefit from the Business’ professional services on their own or together with other readily available resources, the Business considers professional services as distinct within the context of the contract. Professional service revenue is recognized over time so long as: (i) the customer simultaneously receives and consumes the benefits as the Business performs them, (ii) performance creates or enhances an asset the customer controls as the Business performs, and (iii) performance does not create an asset with alternative use and the Business has enforceable right to payment. If all the above criteria are met, the Business uses an input-based measure of progress for recognizing professional service revenue. For example, total labor hours incurred compared to total expected labor hours may be considered. As a practical expedient, when a customer is invoiced at an amount that corresponds directly with the value to the customer of the Business’ performance to date, the Business will recognize revenue at that amount. -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: To the extent that the Business grants a customer an option to acquire additional products or services in one of the arrangements, the Business will account for the option as a distinct performance obligation in the contract only if the option provides a material right to the customer that the customer would not receive without entering into the contract. For example, if a customer is given an option to acquire additional goods or services in the future at a price that is significantly lower than the current price, this would be a material right as it allows the customer to, in effect, pay in advance for the option to purchase future products or services. If a material right exists in one of the contracts, then revenue allocated to the option is deferred and the Business would recognize revenue only when those future products or services are transferred or when the option expires. Based on history, contracts do not typically contain material rights and when they do, the material right is not significant to the Combined Carveout Financial Statements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: Contracts generally contain more than one of the products and services listed above. Determining whether goods and services are considered distinct performance obligations that should be accounted for separately or as a single performance obligation may require judgment, specifically when assessing whether both of the following two criteria are met: - the customer can benefit from the product or service either on its own or together with other resources that are readily available to the customer; and - the Business’ promise to transfer the product or service to the customer is separately identifiable from other promises in the contract. If these criteria are not met, the Business determines an appropriate measure of progress based on the nature of the Business’ overall promise for the single performance obligation. If these criteria are met, each product or service is separately accounted for as a distinct performance obligation and the total transaction price is allocated to each performance obligation on a relative standalone selling price (“SSP”) basis.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: The SSP reflects the price that would be charged for a specific product or service if it were sold separately in similar circumstances and to similar customers. In most cases, the SSP can be established based on observable data. The Business typically establishes a narrow SSP range for the products and services and assess this range on a periodic basis or when material changes in facts and circumstances warrant a review. If the SSP is not directly observable, then the Business estimates the amount using either the expected cost plus a margin or residual approach. Estimating SSP requires judgment that could impact the amount and timing of revenue recognized. SSP is a formal process whereby management considers multiple factors including, but not limited to, geographic or regional specific factors, competitive positioning, internal costs, profit objectives, and pricing practices.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: In bundled arrangements, where the Business has more than one distinct performance obligation, the Business must allocate the transaction price to each performance obligation based on its relative SSP. However, in certain bundled arrangements, the SSP may not always be directly observable. For instance, in bundled arrangements with license and customer support, the Business allocates the transaction price between the license and customer support performance obligations using the residual approach because the Business has determined that the SSP for licenses in these arrangements are highly variable. The Business uses the residual approach only for license arrangements. When the SSP is observable but contractual pricing does not fall within the established SSP range, then an adjustment is required, and the Business will allocate the transaction price between license and customer support based on the relative SSP established for the respective performance obligations. ----- When two or more contracts are entered into at or near the same time with the same customer, the Business evaluates the facts and circumstances associated with the negotiation of those contracts. Where the contracts are negotiated as a package, the Business will account for them as a single arrangement and allocate the consideration for the combined contracts among the performance obligations accordingly.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: The Business executes certain sales contracts through resellers, distributors and channel partners (collectively referred to as resellers). Typically, the Business concludes that the resellers are customers of the Business in reseller agreements. The resellers have control over the pricing, service and products prior to being transferred to the end customer. The Business also assess the creditworthiness of each reseller and if they are newly formed, undercapitalized or in financial difficulty, the Business defers any revenues expected to emanate from such reseller and recognize revenue only when cash is received, and all other revenue recognition criteria under ASC Topic 606 are met.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Title: Rights of return and other incentives
Subsubsection Text: The Business does not generally offer rights of return or any other incentives such as concessions, product rotation, or price protection and, therefore, do not provide for or make estimates of rights of return and similar incentives. Additionally, in some contracts, however, discounts may be offered to the customer for future software purchases and other additional products or services. Such arrangements grant the customer an option to acquire additional products or services in the future at a discount and therefore are evaluated under guidance related to “material rights” as discussed above.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in
Subsubsection Text: Payment terms and conditions vary by contract type, although terms generally include a requirement of payment within 30 to 60 days of the invoice date. In certain arrangements, the Business will receive payment from a customer either before or after the performance obligation to which the invoice relates has been satisfied. As a practical expedient, the Business does not account for significant financing components if the period between when the Business transfers the promised good or service to the customer and when the customer pays for the product or service will be one year or less. On that basis, contracts for license and maintenance typically do not contain a significant financing component, however, in determining the transaction price the Business considers whether there is a need to adjust the promised consideration for the effects of the time value of money if the timing of payments provides either the customer or the Business with a significant benefit of financing. The Business may modify contracts to offer customers additional products or services. The additional products and services will be considered distinct from those products or services transferred to the customer before the modification and will be accounted for as a separate contract. The Business evaluates whether the price for the additional products and services reflects the SSP adjusted as appropriate for facts and circumstances applicable to that contract. In determining whether an adjustment is appropriate, the Business evaluates whether the incremental consideration is consistent with the prices previously paid by the customer or similar customers. Certain of the Business’ product support arrangements generally contain performance response time guarantees. The Business estimates variable consideration on a contract basis because such arrangements are customer-specific. The Business uses an expected value approach to estimate variable consideration based on historical business practices and current and future performance expectations to determine the likelihood of incurring penalties. -----

Subsubsection Title: Incremental Costs of Obtaining a Contract with a Customer
Subsubsection Text: Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs that the Business incurs to obtain a contract that would not have incurred if the contract had not been obtained, such as sales commissions. The Business has determined that certain of the commission programs meet the requirements to be capitalized. Some commission programs are not subject to capitalization as the commission expense is paid and recognized as the related revenue is recognized. In assessing costs to obtain a contract, the Business applies a practical expedient that allows the Business to assess incremental costs on a portfolio of contracts with similar characteristics instead of assessing the incremental costs on each individual contract. The Business does not expect the financial statement effects of applying this practical expedient to the portfolio of contracts to be materially different than if the Business were to apply the standard to each individual contract. The Business pays commissions on the sale of new customer contracts as well as for renewals of existing contracts to the extent the renewals generate incremental revenue. Commissions paid on renewal contracts are limited to the incremental new revenue and therefore these payments are not commensurate with the commission paid on the original sale. The Business allocates commission costs to the performance obligations in an arrangement consistent with the allocation of the transaction price. Commissions allocated to the license performance obligation are expensed at the time the license revenue is recognized. Commissions allocated to professional service performance obligations are expensed as incurred, as these contracts are generally for one year or less and the Business applies a practical expedient to expense costs as incurred if the amortization period would have been one year or less. Commissions allocated to customer support are capitalized and amortized consistent with the pattern of transfer to the customer of the services over the period expected to benefit from the commission payment. As commissions paid on renewals are not commensurate with the original sale, the period of benefit considers anticipated renewals. The benefit period is estimated to be approximately six years which is based on customer contracts and the estimated life of technology. Expenses for incremental costs associated with obtaining a contract are recorded within “Sales and marketing” expense in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income. Short-term capitalized costs to obtain a contract are included in “Prepaid expenses and other current assets”, while long-term capitalized costs to obtain a contract are included in “Other assets” on the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Research and development costs internally incurred in creating computer software to be sold, licensed or otherwise marketed are expensed as incurred unless they meet the criteria for deferral and amortization, as described in ASC Topic 985-20, “Costs of Software to be Sold, Leased, or Marketed” (Topic 985-20). In accordance with Topic 985-20, costs related to research, design and development of products are charged to expense as incurred and capitalized between the dates that the product is considered to be technologically feasible and is considered to be ready for general release to customers. Based on historical experience, the dates relating to the achievement of technological feasibility and general release of the product have substantially coincided. In addition, no significant costs are incurred subsequent to the establishment of technological feasibility. As a result, the Business does not capitalize any research and development costs relating to internally developed software to be sold, licensed or otherwise marketed. |Performance Obligation|When Performance Obligation is Typically Satisfied| |---|---| |Customer support revenue: When and if available updates and upgrades and technical support License revenue: Software licenses (Perpetual and Term) Professional service revenue: Professional services|Ratable over the course of the service term (over time) When software activation keys have been made available for download (point in time) As the services are provided (over time)| -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes as presented in the Business’ Combined Carveout Financial Statements consist of current and deferred income taxes of Parent in a manner that is systematic, rational and consistent with the principles of FASB ASC Topic 740: Income Taxes (“ASC 740”). Accordingly, the Business’ income tax provision was prepared following the separate return method. The separate return method applies ASC 740 to the stand-alone financial statements of each member of the consolidated group as if the group members were a separate taxpayer and a stand-alone enterprise. The calculation of the Business’ income taxes on a separate return basis requires a considerable amount of judgment and use of both estimates and allocations. As a result, actual transactions included in the consolidated financial statements of Parent may not be included in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements. Similarly, the tax treatment of certain items reflected in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements may not be reflected in the consolidated financial statements and tax returns of Parent. Therefore, items such as net operating losses, credit carry-forwards and valuation allowances may exist in the stand-alone financial statements that may or may not exist in Parent’s consolidated financial statements. As such, the income taxes of the Business as presented in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements may not be indicative of the income taxes that the Business will generate in the future. Certain operations of the Business have historically been included in a consolidated tax return with other Parent entities. Current obligations or receivables are deemed settled with Parent as a component of net parent investment for purposes of the Combined Carveout Financial Statements. The effects of tax adjustments and settlements from taxing authorities are presented in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements in the period to which they relate as if the Business were a separate filer. Deferred income taxes are recognized using the asset and liability method on temporary differences arising at the balance sheet date between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts. Deferred income taxes are recalculated annually at tax rates in effect for the years in which those tax assets and liabilities are expected to be realized or settled. The Business records valuation allowances to reduce its deferred tax assets to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized. Deferred tax assets are recognized in respect of all deductible temporary differences, carry-forwards of unused tax credits and unused tax losses to the extent that it is more likely than not that taxable income will be available against which the temporary differences can be utilized. The carrying amounts of deferred tax assets are subject to review at each balance sheet date and are reduced to the extent that future taxable income are considered to be inadequate to allow all or part of any deferred tax asset to be utilized. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are presented on a net basis for the same tax-paying component within the same tax jurisdiction. The Business accounts for uncertain tax provisions by using a two-step approach. The first step is to evaluate the tax position for recognition by determining if the weight of the available evidence indicates it is more likely than not, based solely on the technical merits, that the position will be sustained on audit, including the resolution of related appeals or litigation processes, if any. The second step is to measure the appropriate amount of the benefit to recognize. The amount of benefit to recognize is measured as the maximum amount which is more likely than not to be realized. The tax position is derecognized when it is no longer more likely than not that the position will be sustained on audit. On subsequent recognition and measurement, the maximum amount which is more likely than not to be recognized at each reporting date will represent the Business’ best estimate, given the information available at the reporting date, although the outcome of the tax position is not absolute or final. The Business recognizes both accrued interest and penalties related to liabilities for income taxes within the “Provision for (recovery of) income taxes” line of the Combined Carveout Statements of Income (see Note 10 “Income Taxes” for more details). -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Combined Carveout Financial Statements are presented in U.S. dollars. In general, the functional currency of entities is the local currency. For each subsidiary, assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S dollars at the exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet dates and revenues and expenses are translated at the average exchange rates prevailing during the previous month of the transaction. The effect of foreign currency translation adjustments are recorded as a component of “Accumulated other comprehensive income.” Transactional foreign currency gains (losses) included in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income under the line item “Other income (expense), net” for the year ended December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 were $735 and $(3,262), respectively.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Business has various defined contribution retirement plans around the world covering many of its employees. Under these plans, employees can contribute a portion of their salary to the plan and the Business makes minimum non-elective contributions, discretionary contributions, and matching contributions, depending on the terms of the specific plan. The majority of the plans are primarily located in Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom and Germany. For the year ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, the Business made contributions of $3,466 and $2,643, respectively, relating to the defined contribution retirement plans.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND MORE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Parent operated various equity-settled, share-based compensation plans during the periods and certain employees of the Business participated in the Parent’s plans. Share-based compensation costs are measured in accordance with ASC Topic 718, “Compensation – Stock Compensation” (Topic 718) on the grant date, based on the calculated fair value of the award. The Parent has elected to treat awards with graded vesting as a single award when estimating fair value. Compensation cost is recognized on a straight-line basis over the employee requisite service period, which in the Parent’s circumstance is the stated vesting period of the award, provided that total compensation cost recognized at least equals the pro-rata value of the award that has vested. Compensation cost is initially based on the estimated number of awards for which the requisite service is expected to be rendered. This estimate is adjusted in the period once actual forfeitures are known. ----- ###### Note 3. Revenues

Subsubsection Text: While the Business is domiciled in Canada, due to the percentage of global operations subject to tax in the United Kingdom, the Business uses the UK corporate tax rate in the reconciliation of the effective income tax rate. A reconciliation of the combined UK corporate tax rate with the Business’ effective income tax rate is as follows: Effective Tax Rate Reconciliation of the Business** For the Year Ended December 31, 2023 2022 Income (Loss) before income taxes** $ 260,460 $ 274,410 Expected provision for income taxes 61,208 52,138 Effect of foreign tax rate differences 2,236 7,420 Change in uncertain tax positions 435 (1,580) Effect of permanent differences (1,710) (2,484) Other items 10 53 Effect of rate change differential 39 (317) Effect of tax credits (905) (688) As a result of the increase in the UK corporate tax rate from 19% to 25% beginning April 1, 2023, the applicable UK corporate tax rate for the year ended December 31, 2023 is 23.5%. The effective income tax rate for the year ended December 31, 2023 varied from the statutory tax rate due to the Business' jurisdictional mix of earnings and changes in uncertain tax positions partially offset by permanent differences and available tax credits. The effective income tax rate for the year ended December 31, 2022 varied from the statutory rate due to the Business’ jurisdictional mix of earnings partially offset by available tax credits and changes in uncertain tax positions. Subsubsection Text: The Business regularly evaluates the recoverability of its deferred tax assets and establishes a valuation allowance, if necessary, to reduce the deferred tax assets to an amount that is more likely than not to be realized (a likelihood of more than 50 percent). Significant judgment is required to determine whether a valuation allowance is necessary and the amount of such valuation allowance. The Business continues to evaluate their taxable position and consider factors by taxing jurisdiction, including but not limited to factors such as estimated taxable income, any historical experience of losses for tax purposes and the future growth of the Business. Based upon the available evidence, management expects that the Business will be able to utilize the deferred tax assets (“DTAs”) based upon future estimated taxable income. Subsubsection Text: Included in the above tabular reconciliation are unrecognized tax benefits of $4,869 and $4,434 as of December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, respectively, that if recognized would favorably affect the effective income tax rate. The Business and/or its subsidiaries file income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, and various state, local, and foreign jurisdictions. Interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits were immaterial as of December 31, 2023. ----- The Business and/or its subsidiaries file income tax returns in all major taxing jurisdictions in which the Business operates. The Parent’s tax filings remain subject to audits by applicable tax authorities for a certain length of time following the tax year to which those filings relate. The Parent currently has income tax audits open in Canada, the United States, Germany and other immaterial jurisdictions. As of December 31, 2023, the Business had immaterial deferred income tax liabilities for temporary differences related to the undistributed earnings of certain non-US subsidiaries and planned periodic repatriations from subsidiaries, that would be subject to withholding taxes upon distribution. ###### Note 11. Segment Information ASC Topic 280, “Segment Reporting” (Topic 280), establishes standards for reporting, by public business enterprises, information about operating segments, products and services, geographic areas and major customers. The method of determining what information, under Topic 280, to report is based on the way that an entity organizes operating segments for making operational decisions and how the entity’s management and CODM assess an entity’s financial performance. The Business operates as one segment based upon the information used by the CODM in evaluating the performance of the Business and allocating resources and capital. Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of business, the Business may be involved in various claims and legal proceedings. As of the date of these Combined Carveout Financial Statements, the aggregate of such accrued liabilities was not material to the Business’ Combined Carveout Financial Statements and the Business does not believe as of the date of these Combined Carveout Financial Statements that it is reasonably possible that a loss exceeding the amounts already recognized will be incurred that would be material to the Business’ Combined Carveout Financial Statements. ###### Note 13.
